editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE NIGHT-VVALKER, OR THE LITTLE THIEF.
A COMEDY, As it was preſented by her Majeſties Servants, at the Private Houſe in DRURY-LANE.

div.head: THE NIGHT-WALKER: OR, THE LITTLE THIEF.
Actus primus, Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Tom Lurcher and Iack Wildbrain.

sp.speaker: Lurc.
sp.l: IAcke.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What winde brought thee hither?
In what hollow tree, or rotten wall
Haſt thou been like a Swallow all this Winter,
Where haſt thou been man?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Following the Plow.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What plow?
Thou haſt no Land,
Stealing is thy own purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The beſt inheritance.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Not in my opinion,
Thou hadſt five hundred pound a year.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Tis gone,
Prethee no more on't, have I not told thee,
And oftentimes, nature made all men equal,
Her diſtribution to each child alike;
Till labour came and th •• ſt a new Will in,
Which I allow not: till men won a priviledge
By that they call endeavour, which indeed
Is nothing but a lawful Coſenage,
An allowed way to cheat, why ſhould my neighbour
That hath no more ſoul than his Horſe-keeper,
Nor bounteous faculties above a Broom-man,
Have fourty thouſand pound, and I four groats;
Why ſhould he keep it?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Thy old opinion ſtill.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Why ſhould that Scrivener
That ne're writ reaſon in his life, nor any thing
That time ere gloried in, that never knew
How to keep any curteſie conceal'd,
But Noverint univerſi muſt proclaim it,
Purchaſe perpetually, and I a raſcal:
Conſider this, why ſhould that mouldy Cobler
Marry his daughter to a wealthy Merchant,
And give five thouſand pound, is this good juſtice?
Becauſe he has a tougher conſtitution;
Can feed upon old ſongs, and ſave his money,
Therefore muſt I go beg?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: What's this to thee?
Thou canſt not mend, if thou beeſt determin'd
To rob all like a tyrant, yet take heed
A keener juſtice do not overtake thee,
And catch you in a Nooze.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I am no Wood-cock,
He that ſhall ſit down frighted with that foolery
Is not worth pity, let me alone to ſhuffle,
Thou art for wenching.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: For beauty I, a ſafe courſe,
No halter hangs in the way, I defie it.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: But a worſe fate, a wilful poverty,
For where thou gainſt by one that indeed loves thee,
A thouſand will draw from thee, 'tis thy deſtiny;
One is a kind of weeping croſs Iack,
A gentle purgatory, do not fling at all,
You'le pay the Box ſo often, till you periſh.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Take you no care for that ſir, 'tis my pleaſure,
I will imploy my wits a great deal faſter
Then you ſhall do your ſingers, and my Loves,
If I miſtake not, ſhall prove riper harveſt
And handſomer, and come within leſs danger.
Where's thy young ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I Know not where ſhe is, ſhe is not worth caring for,
She has no wit.
Oh you'd be nibling with her,
She's far enough I hope, I know not where,
She's not worth caring for, a fullen thing,
She wo'd not take my counſel Iack,
And ſo I parted from her.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Leave her to her wants?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I gave her a little money what I could ſpare,
She had a mind to th' Countrey, she is turn'd
By this ſome Farriers dairy maid, I may meet her
Riding from market one day 'twixt her Dorſers,
If I do, by this hand I wo' not ſpare
Her butter pence.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Thou wilt not rob thy ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: She ſhall account me for her Egges and Cheeſes.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: A pretty Girle, did not old Algript love her?
A very pretty Girle ſhe was.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Some ſuch thing,
But he was too wiſe to faſten; let her paſs.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Then where's thy Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Where you ſha'not find her,
Nor know what ſtuffe ſhe is made on, no indeed ſir,
I choſe her not for your uſe.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Sure ſhe is handſome.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Yes indeed is ſhe, ſhe is very handſome, but that's all one.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: You'le come toth' marriage.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Is it to day.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Now, now, they are come from Church now.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Any great preparation,
Does Juſtice Algripe ſhew his power.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Very glorious, and glorious people there.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I may meet with him yet e're I dye as cunning as he is.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: You may do good Tom at the marriage,
We have plate and dainty things.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Do you no harm ſir;
For yet me thinks the marriage ſhould be mar'd
If thou maiſt have thy will, farewel, ſay nothing. Exit. Enter Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: You are welcome noble friends.
I thank you ſir,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Nephew to the old Lady, his name is Wildbrain,
And wild his beſt condition.
I have heard of him,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I pray ye tell me ſir, is young Maria merry
After her marriage rites? does ſhe look lively?
How does ſhe like her man?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Very ſcurvely,
And as untowardly she prepares her ſelf,
But 'tis mine Aunts will, that this dull mettal
Muſt be mixt with her to allay her handſomeneſs.
Had Heartlove no faſt friends?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: His means are little,
And where thoſe littles are, as little comforts
Ever keep company: I know ſhe loves him,
His memory beyond the hopes of—
Beyond the Indies in his mouldy Cabinets,
But 'tis her unhandſome fate. Enter Heartlove.
I am ſorry for't,
Here comes poor Frank, nay we are friends, ſtart not Sir,
We ſee you'r willow and are ſorry for't,
And though it be a wedding we are half mourners.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Good Gentlemen remember not my fortunes,
They are not to be help'd by words.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Look up man,
A proper ſenſible fellow and ſhrink for a Wench,
Are there no more? or is ſhe all the handſomeneſs?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Prethee leave fooling.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Prethee leave thou whining,
Have maids forgot to love?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You are injurious.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Let 'em alone a while, thei'le follow thee.
Come good Frank.
Forget now, ſince there is no remedy,
And ſhew a merry face, as wiſe men would do.
Be a free gueſt, and think not of thoſe paſſages.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Think how to nick him home, thou knoweſt ſhe dotes on thee;
Graff me a dainty medler on his crabſtocke;
Pay me the dreaming puppy.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Well, make your mirth, the whilſt I bear my miſery:
Honeſt minds would have better thoughts.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I am her kinſman,
And love her well, am tender of her youth,
Yet honeſt Frank, before I would have that ſtinkard,
That walking rotten tombe, enjoy her maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Prethee leave mocking.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Prethee Frank believe me,
Go to conſider, harke, they kn • ck to dinner. Kn • ck within.
Come wo't thou go?
I preethee Frank go with us,
And laugh and dance as we do.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: You are light Gentlemen,
Nothing to weigh your hearts, pray give me leave,
Ile come and ſee, and take my leave.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Wee'le look for you,
Do not deſpair, I have a trick yet. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Yes,
When I am miſchievous I will believe your projects:
She is gone, for ever gone, I cannot help it,
My hopes and all my happineſs gone with her.
Gone like a pleaſing dream: what mirth and jollity
Raignes round about this houſe? how every office
Sweats with new joyes, can ſhe be merry too?
Is all this pleaſure ſet by her appointment?
Sure ſhe hath a falſe heart then; ſtill they grow lowder,
The old mans God, his gold, has won upon her
(Light hearted Cordial gold) and all my ſervices
That offered naked truth, are clean forgotten:
Yet if ſhe were compel'd, but it cannot be,
If I could but imagine her will mine, Enter Lady and Wildbrain.
Although he had her body.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He ſhall come in.
Walk without doors o' this day, though an enemy,
It muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: You muſt compel him Madam,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No ſhe ſhall fetch him in, Nephew it ſhall be ſo.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: It will be fitteſt. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Can fair Maria look agen upon me?
Can there be ſo much impudence in ſweetneſs? Enter Maria.
Or has ſhe got a ſtrong heart to defie me?
She comes her ſelf: how rich ſhe is in Jewels!
Me thinks they ſhow like frozen Iſicles,
Cold winter had hung on her, how the Roſes
That kept continual ſpring within her cheeks
Are witheered with old mans dull imbraces?
She would ſpeak to me. I can ſigh too Lady
But from a ſounder heart: yes, and can weep too
But 'tis for you, that ever I believ'd you,
Tears of more pious value than your marriage;
You would encaſe your ſelf, and I muſt credit you,
So much my old obedience compels from me;
Go, and forget me, and my poverty,
I need not bid you, you are too perfect that way:
But ſtill remember that I lov'd Maria,
Lov'd with a loyal love, nay turn not from me,
I will not ask a treare more, you are bountiful,
Go and rejoyce, and I will wait upon you
That little of my life left.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good ſir hear me,
What has been done, was the act of my obedience
And not my will: forc'd from me by my parents,
Now 'tis done, do as I do, bear it handſomly
And if there can be more ſociety
Without diſhonour to my tye of marriage
Or place for noble love, I ſhall love you ſtill,
You had the firſt, the laſt, had my will proſper'd;
You talk of little time of life: dear Franke,
Certain I am not married for eternity,
The joy my marriage brings tells me I am mortal.
And ſhorter liv'd then you, elſe I were miſerable;
Nor can the gold and eaſe his age hath brought me
Adde what I coveted, content, go with me,
They ſeek a day of joy, prethce let's ſhow it,
Though it be forc'd, and by this kiſs believe me
However, I muſt live at his command now,
Ile dye at yours.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I have enough, Ile honour ye. Exeunt. Enter Lurcher.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Here are my trinkets, and this luſty marriage
I mean to viſit, I have ſhift of all ſorts,
And here are a thouſand wheeles to ſet'em working,
I am very merry, for I know this wedding
Will yield me luſty pillage, if mad VVildgooſe
That deboſh'd rogue keep but his antient revells,
And breed a hubbub in the houſe I am happy. Enter Boy.
Now what are you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A poor diſtreſſed Boy Sir,
Friendleſs and comfortleſs, that would entreat
Some charity and kindneſs from your worſhip,
I would fain ſerve Sir, and as fain indeavour
With dutious labour to deſerve the love
Of that good Gentleman ſhall entertain me.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A pretty boy, but of too milde a breeding,
Too tender and too baſhfull a behaviour,
What canſt thou do?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: I can learn any thing,
That's good and honeſt, and ſhall pleaſe Maſter.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: He bluſhes as he ſpeaks, and that I like not,
I love a bold and ſecure confidence,
An impudence that one may truſt, this boy now
Had I inſtructed him had been a Jewel,
A treaſure for my uſe, thou canſt not lye.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I would not willingly.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nor thou haſt not wit
To diſſemble neatly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Do you love ſuch boyes, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Oh mainly, mainly, I would have my boy impudent,
Out-face all truth, yet do it piouſly:
Like Proteus, caſt himſelf into all forms,
As ſudden and as nimble as his thoughts,
Blanch at no danger, though it be the Gallowes,
Nor make no conſcience of a coſonage
Though it be ith' Church; your ſoft, demure, ſtill children—
Are good for nothing, but to get long graces—
And ſing ſongs to dull tunes; I would keep thee
And cheriſh thee, hadſt thou any active quality,
And be a tender Maſter to thy knavery,
But thou art not for my uſe.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Do you ſpeak this ſeriouſly?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Yes indeed do I.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Would you have your boy Sir
Read in theſe moral miſchiefs?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Now thou mov'ſt me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: And be a well train'd youth in all activities?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: By any means.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Or do you this to try me,
Fearing a proneneſs.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I ſpeake this to make thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Then take me Sir, and cheriſh me, and love me,
You have me what you would: believe me Sir
I can do any thing for your advantage,
I gueſs at what you mean; I can can lie naturally,
As eaſily, as I can ſleep Sir, and ſecurely:
As naturally I can ſteal too.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: That I am glad on,
Right heartily glad on, hold thee there, thou art excellent.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Steal any thing from any body living.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Not from thy Maſter.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: That's mine own body:
And muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The Boy mends mightily.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: A rich man, that like ſnow, heaps up his moneys,
I have a kind of pious zeal to meet ſtill;
A fool that not deſerves 'em, I take pitty on,
For fear he ſhould run mad, and ſo I eaſe him.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Excellent boy, and able to inſtruct me,
Of my own nature juſt.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I ſcorn all hazard,
And on the edge of danger I do beſt ſir,
I h • ve a thouſand faces to deceive,
And to thoſe twice ſo many tongues to flatter,
An impudence, no braſs was ever tougher,
And for my conſcience.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Peace, I have found a Jewel,
A Jewel all the Indies cannot match,
And thou ſha't feel—

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: This title, and I ha'done ſir;
I never can confeſs, I ha' that ſpell on me;
And ſuch rare modeſties before a Magiſtrate,
Such Innocence to catch a Judge, ſuch ignorance.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Ile learn of thee, thou art mine own, come Boy,
Ile give thee action preſently.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Have at you.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What muſt I call thee?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Snap ſir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt natural,
A name born to thee, ſure thou art a Fairie,
Shew but thy skill, and I ſhall make thee happie. Enter Lady, Nurſe, Miſtreſs, Newlove, Tobie.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Where be theſe Knaves? who ſtrues up all the liveries.
Is the brides bed made?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: Yes Madam and a bell
Hung under it artificially.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Out knave out,
Muſt we have larums now?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: A little warning
That we may know when to begin our healths Madam,
The Juſtice is a kinde of old Jade Madam,
That will go mer • ieſt with a bell.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: All the houſe drunk.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: This is a day of Jubile.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A • e the beſt hangings up, and the plate ſet out?
Who makes the Poſſet, Nurſe?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: The dairie mayd,
And ſhe • 'le put that in, will make him caper:
Well Madam, well, you might ha'choſe another,
A handſomer for your years.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Peace, he is rich Nurſe,
He is rich, and that's beauty.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: I am ſure he is rotten,
Would he had been hang'd when he firſt ſaw her. Termagant!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What an angry quean is this, where,
Who looks to him?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: He is very merry Madam,
M. Wildbrain, has him in hand, ith' bottom oth' Sellar
He ſighes and tipples.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Alas good Gentleman,
My heart's ſore for thee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sorrow muſt have his courſe, ſirra,
Give him ſome Sack to dry up his remembrance,
How does the Bridegroom, I am afraid of him.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: He is a trim youth to be tender of, hemp take him.
Muſt my ſweet new blown Roſe find ſuch a winter
Before her ſpring be near.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Peace, peace, thou art fooliſh.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: And dances like a Town-top: and reels, and hobbles.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas, good Gentleman, give him not much wine,

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: He ſhall ha' none by my conſent.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Are the women comforting my daughter?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Yes, yes, Madam,
And reading to her a pattern of true patience,
They read and pray for her too.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: They had need,
Ye had better marry her to her grave a great deal:
There will be peace and reſt, alas poor Gentlewoman,
Muſt ſhe become a Nurſe now in her tenderneſs?
Well Madam, well my heart bleeds.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou art a fool ſtill.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Pray heaven I be.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And an old fool to be vext thus.
Tis late ſhe muſt to bed, go knave be merry,
Drinke for a boy, away to all your charges. Exit. Enter Wildbrain, and Franke Heartlove.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Do as thou wo't, but if thou doſt refuſe it
Thou art the ſtupid'ſt aſſe, there's no long arguing,
Time is too precious Franke.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I am hot with wine,
And apt now to believe, but if thou doſt this.
Out of a villany, to make me wrong her,
As thou art prone enough.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Does ſhe not love thee?
Did ſhe not cry down-right e'en now to part with thee?
Had she not ſwounded if I had not caught her?
Canſt thou have more?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs all this.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Do not ſtand prating, and miſdoubting, caſting,
If ſhe go from thee now, ſhe's loſt for ever;
Now now ſhe's going, ſhe that loves thee going,
She whom thou lov'ſt.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Pray let me think a little:

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: There is no leiſure; think when thou haſt imbrace'd her.
Can ſhe imagine thou didſt ever honour her?
Ever believe thy oathes, that tamely ſuffer'ſt
An old dry ham of horſe-fleſh to enjoy her?
Enjoy her Maiden head; take but that from her
That we may tell poſterity a man had it,
A handſome man, a gentleman, a young man,
To ſave the honour of our houſe, the credit,
Tis no great matter I deſire.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I hear you.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Free us both from the fear of breeding fools
And ophs, got by this ſhadow: we talke too long.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: She is going to bed, among the women,
What opportunity can I have to meet her?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Let me alone, haſt thou a will? ſpeak ſoundly,
Speak diſcreetly, ſpeak home and handſomely,
Iſt not pitty, nay miſery, nay inſamy to leave
So rare a pie to be cut up by a raskall.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I will go preſently, now, now, I ſtay thee.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Such a dainty Doe, to be taken
By one that knows not necke-beefe from a Pheſant,
Nor cannot relliſh Braggat from Ambroſia.
Is it not conſcience?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Yes, yes, now I feel it.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: A meritorious thing.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Good Father Wildgooſe,
I do confeſs it.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Come then follow me.
And pluck a mans heart up, Ile locke thee privately,
Where ſhe alone ſhall preſently paſs by,
None near to interupt thee but be ſure;

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I ſhall be ſure enough, lead on, and crown me.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: No wringings in your mind now as you love me. Ex. Enter Lady, Maria, Iuſtice, Gent. Nurſe, Newlove.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Tis time you were a bed.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I prethee ſweet-heart
Conſider my neceſſity, why art ſad?
I muſt tell you a tale in your ear anon.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Of Tom Thumb.
I believe that will prove your ſtiffeſt ſtory.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: I pitty the young wench.
And ſo do I too.
Come, old ſtickes take fire.
But the Plague is, he'l burn out inſtantly;
Give him another cup.
Thoſe are but flaſhes,
A tun of ſack wonot ſet him high enough.
Will ye to bed?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I muſt.
Come, have a good heart,
And win him like a bowle to lye cloſe to you,
Make your beſt uſe.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Nay prethee Duck go inſtantly,
Ile daunce a Jig or two to warme my body. Enter Wildbrain.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Tis almoſt midnight.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Prethee to bed Maria.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Go you afore, and let the Ladies follow,
And leave her to her thoughts a while, there muſt be
A time of taking leave of the ſame fooleries
Bewailing others maiden-heads.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Come then,
We'l wait in the nex room.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Do not tarry.
For if thou doſt, by my troth I ſhall fall aſleep Mall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Do, do, and dream of D •• rells, get you to bed quickly,
A • d let us ha'no more ſtir, come no, crying,
'Tis too late now, carry your ſelves diſcreetly.
The old thief loves thee dearly, thats the benefit.
For the reſt you muſt make your own play, Nay not that way,
Theil pull ye all to pieces, for your whim-whams,
Your garters and your gloves, go modeſtly,
And privately ſteal to bed, 'tis very late Mall,
For if you go by them ſuch a new larum.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I know not which way to avoid'em.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: This way,
This through the Cloiſters: and ſo ſteal to bed,
When you are there once, all will ſeparate
And give ye reſt, I came out of my pity
To ſhew you this.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Here's the keyes,
Go preſently and lock the doors faſt after ye,
That none ſhall follow.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Good night.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Good night ſweet Coſen,
A good, and ſweet night, or Ile cu • ſe thee Frank. Exit. Enter Frank Hartlove.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: She ſtayes long, ſure young Wildgooſe has abus'd me,
He has made ſport wi'me, I may yet get out again,
And I may ſee his face once more, I ha foul intentions,
But they are drawn on by a fouler dealing. Enter Maria.
Hark, hark, it was the door,
Something comes this way, wondrous ſtill, and ſtealing
May be ſome walking ſpirit to affright me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Oh heaven my fortune.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: 'Tis her voice, ſtay.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Save me,
Bleſs me you better powers.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I am no Devil.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Y'are little better to diſturb me now.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: My name is Hartlove.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Fye, fye, worthy friend.
Fye noble ſir.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I muſt talk farther with ye,
You know my fair affection.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: So preſerve it,
You know I am married now, for ſhame be civiller,
Not all the earth ſhall make me.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Pray walk this way,
And if you ever lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Take heed Frank
How you divert that love to hate, go home prethee.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Shall he enjoy that ſweet?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, pray unhand me.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: He that never felt what love was.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Then I charge you ſtand further off.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I am tame, but let me walk wi'ye,
Talk but a minute.

sp.speaker: M • r.
sp.l: So your talk be honeſt,
And my untainted honour ſuffer not;
Ile walk a turn or two.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Give me your hand then. Exit. Enter, Wildbrain, Iustice, Lady, Nurſe, Gent. Women, Newlove.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.l: Shee's not in her Chamber.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: She is not here.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: And Ile tell you what I dream'd.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Give me a Torch.

sp.speaker: 1. G.
sp.l: Be not too haſty fir.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Nay let him go.
For if my dream be true, he muſt be ſpeedy,
He will be trickt, and blaz'd elſe.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: As I am a woman
I cannot blame her if ſhe take her liberty,
Would ſhe would make thee cuckold, thou old bully,
A notorious cuckold for tormenting her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ile hang her then.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Ile bleſs her then, ſhe does juſtice,
Is this old ſtinking doggs fleſh for her dyet?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Prethee honeſt Nurſe do not fret too much,
For fear I dream youle hang your ſelf too.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.l: The Cloiſter?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Such was my fancy, I do not ſay 'tis true,
Nor do I bid you be too confident.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Where are the keyes, the keyes I ſay.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I dream'd ſhe had' • m to lock her ſelf in.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: What a Devil do you mean?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: No harme, good Nurſe be patient.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: They are not in the window, where they uſe to be.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: What fooliſh dreams are theſe?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I am mad.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I hope ſo,
If you be not mad, Ile do my beſt to make yee.
This is ſome tricke.
I ſmell the Wildgooſe.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Come gentlemen, come quickely I beſeech you,
Quicke as you can, this may be your caſe Gentlemen.
And bring ſome lights, ſome lights. Exit.

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: Move faſter, faſter, you I come too late elſe.
Ile ſtay behind and pray for ye, I had rather she were dishoneſt,
Than thou shouldſt have her. Enter Maria and Francke.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Y're moſt unmanly. yet I have ſome breath left;
And this ſteel to defend me, come near me,
For if you offer but another violence,
As I have life Ile kill you, if I miſs that,
Vpon my own heart will I execute,
And let that fair beleefe out, I had of you.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Moſt vertuous Maid, I have done, forgive my follies:
Pardon, O pardon, I now ſee my wickedneſs,
And what a monſtrous shape it puts upon me,
On your fair hand I ſeal. Enter Iu.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Down with the door.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: We are betraid, oh Francke, Franke,

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Ile dye for ye
Rather than you shall ſuffer, Ile—

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Now Enter. Enter All.
Enter ſweet Gentlemen, mine eyes, mine eyes,
Oh how my head akes.
Is it poſſible?
Hold her, she ſinkes.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A plot upon my honour
To poyſon my fair name, a ſtudied villany.
Farewell, as I have hope of peace, I am honeſt,

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: My brains, my brains, my monſtrous brains, they bud ſure.

sp.speaker: Nu.
sp.l: She is gone, she is gone.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: A handſome riddance of her.
Would I could as eaſily loſe her memory.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Is this the ſweet of Marriage, have I bred thee
For this reward?
Hold, hold, he's deſperate too.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Be ſure ye hold him faſt, weele bind him over
To the next Seſſions, and if I can, Ile hang him.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Nay then Ile live to be a terrour to thee,
Sweet Virgin Roſe farewell: heaven has thy beauty,
That's onely fit for heaven. Ile live a little
To find the villain out that wrought this injury,
And then moſt bleſſed ſoul, Ile climbe up to thee.
Farewell, I feel my ſelf another creature. Exit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh miſery of miſeries.

sp.speaker: Nu.
sp.l: I told ye Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Carry her in, you will pay back her portion.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: No not a penny, pay me back my credit,
And Ile condition we'ye.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A ſad wedding,
Her grave mnſt be her Bridal bed, oh Mall,
Would I had wed thee to thy own content,
Then I had had thee ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: I am mad, farewell,
Another wanton wife will prove a hell. Exeunt.

l.stage: Enter Tom Lurch. and his Boy.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What haſt thou done?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I have walked through all the lodgings.
A ſilence as if death dwelt there inhabits.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What haſt thou ſeen?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Nought but a ſad confuſion
Every thing left in ſuch a looſe diſorder
That were there twenty theeves, they would be laden.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: 'Tis very Well, I like thy care, but 'tis ſtrange
A wedding night ſhould be ſo ſolitary

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Certainly there is ſome cauſe, ſome death or ſickneſs
Is falne ſuddenly upon ſome friend,
Or ſome ſtrange news is come.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Are they all a bed?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I think ſo, and ſound a ſleep, unleſs it be
Some women that keep watch in a low parlour,
And drink, and weep, I know not to what end.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Where's all the plate?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why lockt up in that room.
I ſaw the old Lady, • re ſhe went to bed
Put up her plate, and ſome of the rich hangings
In a ſmal long cheſt, her chains and rings are there too,
It ſtands cloſe by the Table on a form.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Twas a good notice, didſt thou ſee the men.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I ſaw them ſad too, and all take their leaves,
But what they ſaid I was too far to her ſir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Tis daintily diſcover'd, we ſhall certainly
Have a moſt proſperous night, which way.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A cloſe one,
A back door, that the women have left open,
To go in and out to fetch neceſſaries,
Cloſe on the Garden ſide.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I love diligence,
Wert thou not fearful.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Fearful? Ile be hang'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Say they had ſpied thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I was then determin'd
To have cry'd down right too, and have kept 'em company,
As one that had an intereſt in their ſadneſs,
Or made an errand to I know not whom ſir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My dainty Boy, let us diſcharge, that plate
Makes a perpetual motion in my fingers,
Till I have faſt hold of it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Pray be wiſe ſir, doe't handſomly, be not greedy,
Lets handle it with ſuch an excellence
As if we would bring theeving into honour:
We muſt diſguiſe, to fright theſe reverend watches.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Still my bleſt Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: And clear the Room of drunken jealouſies,
The cheſt is of ſome weight, and we may make
Such noiſe ith' the carriage we may be ſnap'd.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Come open, here's a Devils face.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No, no, ſir, weele have no ſhape ſo terrible,
We will not do the Devil ſo much pleaſure,
To have him face our plot.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A winding ſh • et then.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Thats too cold a ſhift,
I would not wear the reward of my wickedneſs,
I wonder you are an old thief, and no cunninger,
Where's the long Cloak?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Give me the Turbant
And the falſe beard, I hear ſome coming this way,
Stoop, ſtoop, and let me ſit upon your ſhoulders,
And now as I direct: ſtay let'em enter,
And when I touch move forward, make no noiſe. Enter Nurſe and Tobie.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Oh 'its a ſad time, all the burnt wine is burnt Nick.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: We may thank your dry chaps for't, the Canaries gone too
No ſubſtance for a ſorrowful mind to work upon,
I cannot mourn in beer, if ſhe ſhould walk now
As diſcontented ſpirits are wont to do.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: And meet us in the Cellar.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: What fence have we with ſingle beer againſt her?
VVhat heart can we defie the Devil with?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: The March beer's open.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: A fortification of March beer will do well,
I muſt co • feſs 'tis a moſt mighty Armour,
For I preſume I cannot pray.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: VVhy Nicholas?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: VVe Coachmen have ſuch tumbling faiths, no pray'rs
Can go an even pace.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Hold up your candle.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: Ver • ly Nurſe, I have cry'd ſo much
For my young M • ſtreſs, that is mortified,
That if I have not more ſack to ſupport me;
I ſhall even ſleep, heiho, for another flagon;
Theſe Burials and Chriſtnings are the mournful • matters,
And they ask more drink.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Drink to a ſad heart's needful.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Mine's ever ſad, for I am ever dry Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Me thinks the light burns blew, I prethee ſnuffe it,
There's a thief in't I think.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: There may be one near it.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Whats that that moves there, ith' name of—Nicholas?
That thing that walks.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Would I had a ladder to behold it,
Mercy upon me, the Ghoſt of one oth' Guard ſure,
'Tis the devil by his clawes, he ſmalls of Brimſtone,
Sure he farts fire, what an Earth-quake I have in me;
Out with thy Prayer-book Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: It ſelf ith' the frying-pan, and the Cat's eat it.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: I have no power to pray, it grows ſtill longer,
'Tis Steeple high now, and it ſails away Nurſe.
Lets call the Butler up, for he ſpeaks Latine,
And that will daunt the devil: I am blaſted,
My belly's grown to nothing.

sp.speaker: Nu.
sp.l: Fye, fye, Tobi • . Exit.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: So let them go, and whilſt they are aſtoniſh'd.
Let us preſently upon the reſt now ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Off, off, and up agen, when we are near the Parlour,
Art ſure thou knowſt the Cheſt?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Though it were ith' dark ſir,
I can go to't.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: On then and be happy. Exit. Enter Tobie.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: How my haunches quake, is the thing here ſtill?
Now can I out-do any Button-maker, at his own trade,
I have fifteen fits of an Ague, Nurſe, 'tis gone I hope,
The hard-hearted woman has left me alone. Nurſe—
And ſhe knows too I ha but a lean conſcience to keep me company. Noiſe within.
The devil's among 'em in the Parlour ſure,
The Ghoſt three ſtories high, he has the Nurſe ſure,
He is boyling of her bones now, hark how ſhe whiſtles:
There's Gentlewomen within too, how will they do?
Ile to the Cook, for he was drunk laſt night,
And now he is valiant, he is a kin to th' devil too,
And fears no fire, Enter Lurcher and Boy.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No light?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: None left ſir,
They are gone, and carried all the candles with 'em,
Their fright is infinite, let's make good uſe on't,
We muſt be quick ſir, quick, or the houſe will riſe elſe.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: VVas this the Cheſt?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: There was two of 'em.
Or I miſtake.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I know the right, no ſtay ſir,
Nor no diſcourſe, but to our labour luſtily,
Put to your ſtrength and make as little noiſe,
Then preſently out at the back door.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Come Boy.
Come happy child and let me hug thy excellence. Exit. Enter Wildbrain.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: VVhat thouſand noiſes paſs through all the rooms?
VVhat cryes and hurries? ſure the devil's drunk.
And tumbles through the houſe, my villanies
That never made me apprehend before
Danger or fear, a little now moleſt me;
My Coſens death ſits heavy o'my conſcience,
VVould I had been half hang'd when I hammer'd it.
I aim'd at a living divorce, not a burial
That Frank might have had ſome hope: hark ſtill
In every room confuſion, they are all mad,
Moſt certain all ſtark mad within the houſe,
A puniſhment inflicted for my lewdneſs,
That I might have the more ſenſe of my miſchief,
And run the more mad too, my Aunt is hang'd ſure,
Sure hang'd her ſelf, or elſe the fiend has fetc'd her;
I heard a hundred cryes, the Devil, the Devil,
Then roaring and then tumbling, all the chambers
Are a meer Babel, or another Bedlam.
VVhat ſhould I think? I ſhake my ſelf too:
Can the Devil find no time, but when we are merry,
Here's ſomething comes. Enter Newlove.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Oh that I had ſome company,
I care not what they were, to eaſe my miſery,
To comfort me,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: VVhoſe that?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Again? noy then receive—

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Hold, hold I am no fury.
The Merchants wife,

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Are ye a man? pray heaven you be.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Alas I have met ſir
The ſtrangeſt things to night.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: VVhy do you ſtare.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Pray comfort me, and put your candle out,
For if I ſee the ſpirit again I dye for't.
And hold me faſt, for I ſhall ſhake to pieces elſe.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Ile warrant you, Ile hold ye,
Hold ye as tenderly; I have put the light out,
Retire into my Chamber, there Ile watch we'ye,
Ile keep you from all frights.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: And will ye keep me.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Keep you as ſecure Lady.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: You muſt not wrong me then, the devil will have us.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: No, no, Ile love you, then the devil will fear us.
For he fears all that love, pray come in quickly,
For this is the malicious houſe he walks in,
The hour he blaſts ſweet faces, lames the limbs in,
Depraves the ſenſes, now within this half hour
He will have power to turn all Citizens wives
Into ſtrange creatures, Owles, and long-taild Monkeys,
Jayes, Pies, and Parrots, quickly, I ſmell his brimſtone.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: It comes agen I am gone ſhift for your ſelf ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: Sure this whole night is nothing but • lluſion,
Here's nothing comes, all they are mad, damd devil
To drive her back agen, 't had been thy policy
To have let us alone, we might have done ſome fine thing
To have made thy hel-hood laugh, tis a dainty wench,
If I had her again, not all your fellow goblins
Nor all their clawes ſhould ſcratch her hence, Ile ſtay ſtill,
May be her fright will bring her back a gen,
Yet I will hope. Enter Toby.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: I can find no bed, no body, nor no chamber,
Sure they are all ith' Cellar, and I cannot find that neither,
I am led up and down like a tame aſs, my light's out
And I grope up and down like • lind-man buffe,
And break my face, and break • y pa • e.

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: It comes again ſure
I ſee the ſhadow, Ile have faſter hold now,
Sure ſhe is mad, I long to lye with a mad-woman,
She muſt needs have rare new tricks.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: I hear one whiſper
If it be the devil now to allure me into his clutches,
For devils have a kind of tone like crickets,
I have a glimpſe of her guiſe, 'tis ſhe would ſteal me,
But Ile ſtand ſure.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: I have but a dram of wit left,
And that's even ready to run, oh for my bed now.

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: She nam'd a bed, I like that, ſhe repents ſure,
Where is ſhe now?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: Are you there, In, In, In preſently.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: I feel his talents through me,
'Tis an old haggard devil, what will he do with me?

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: Let me kiſs thee firſt, quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: A leacherous Devil.

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: What a hairy whore 'tis, ſure ſhe has a muffler.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.l: If I ſhould have a young Satan by him, tor I dare not deny him,
In what caſe were I? who durſt deliver me?

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: 'Tis but my fancy, ſhe is the ſame, in quickly, gently my
Sweet girle.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Sweet devil be good to me. Ex •• nt. Enter Lurch. and Boy.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: VVhere's my love, Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: She,s coming with a Candle
To ſee our happy prize.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I am cruel weary.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I cannot blame ye, plate is very heavy
To carry without light or help.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The fear too
At every ſtumble to be diſcovered boy,
At every cough to raife a Conſtable,
VVell, wee'le be merry now.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: VVe have ſome reaſon;
Things compaſs'd without fear or eminent danger,
Are too luxurious ſir to live upon.
Money and wealth got thus are as full venture,
And carry in their nature as much merit
As his, that digs 'em out 'oth mine, they laſt too
Seaſon'd with doubts and dangers moſt delitiouſly,
Riches that fall upon us are too ripe,
And dull our appetites.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Moſt learned child. Enter Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Y'are welcome, where have you left it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: in the next room, hard by.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Is it plate all.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: All, all, and Jewels, I am monſtrous weary,
Prethee let's go to bed.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Prethee let's ſee it firſt.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Tomorrow's a new day ſweet.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Yes to melt it,
But let's agree to night, how it ſhall be handled,
Ile have a new gown.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Shat have any thing.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: And ſuch a riding ſuite as Miſtreſs Newloves,
VVhat though I be no Gentlewoman born,
I hope I may atehieve it by my carriage.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Thou ſayſt right.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: You promis'd me a horſe too, and a lackquay.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thou ſhat have horſes ſix, and a poſtilion.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: That will be ſtately ſweet heart a poſtilion.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Nay wee'le be in faſhion he ſhall ride before us
In winter, with as much dirt would dampe a musket,
The inſide of our coach ſhall be of ſcarlet.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: That will be deer.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: There is a dye projecting
Will make it cheape wench, come thou ſhalt have any thing.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Where is this cheſt, I long ſweete to behold
Our Jndies.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: Miſtreſſe lets melt it firſt, and then tis ſit
You ſhould diſpoſe it, then tis ſafe from danger.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Ile be a loving Miſtreſſe to my boy too.
Now fetch it in and lets rejoyce upon't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Hold youre light Miſtreſſe, we may •• e to enter.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Ha whats here? call you this a cheſt?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: We ha miſt ſir.
Our haſt and want of light made us miſtake.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: A very Coffin.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: How! a Coffin? Boy, Tis very like one.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: The devill ow'd us a ſhame, and now he has paid us.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Is this your Treaſure?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: Bury me alive in't.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: It may be there is no roome.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Nay, I will ſearch it:
Ile ſee what wealth's within,—a womans face,
And a faire womans.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I cannot tell ſir,
Belike this was the ſadneſſe that poſſeſt 'em;
The plate ſtood next, I'me Iure.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I ſhake I ſhake Boy, what a cold ſweat—

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: This may worke, what will become on's ſir?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: She is cold, dead cold: de'e find' your conſcience,
De'e bring your Gillians hither—nay, ſhee's puniſh'd,
Your conceal'd love's caſ'd up?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Tis Maria, the very ſame, the Bride, new horror.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Theſe are fine tricks, you hope ſhee's in a ſound,
But Ile take order ſhe ſhall ne'r recover
To bore my noſe, come, take her up and bury her
Quickly, or Ile cry out; take her up inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Be not ſo haſty foole, that may undoe us;
We may be in for murther ſo; be patient,
Thou ſeeſt ſhe's dead, and cannot injure thee.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: I am ſure ſhe ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Be not ſir dejected,
Too much a ſtrange miſtake! this had not been elſe,
It makes me almoſt weep to think upon't.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What an unluckie theef am I?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Ile no conſidering, either beſtir your ſelf, or—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Let it not ſtay, to ſmell then, I will not
Indure the ſtink of a Rival.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Would twere there agen.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: We muſt bury her.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: But where o'th ſudden, or with what providence,
That no eyes watch us.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Take a Spade and follow me,
The next fair ground we meet, make the Church-yard;
As I live, Ile ſee her lodg'd. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: It muſt be ſo,
How heavy my heart is, I ha no life left.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I am paſt thinking too, no underſtanding,
That I ſhould miſſe the right Cheſt.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: The happy Cheſt.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That, which I ſaw and markt too.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Well paſſion wo'not help us,
Had I twenty fals for this?

sp.speaker: Boy,
sp.l: Twas my fault ſir.
And twenty thouſand fears for this, oth'devil,
Now could I curſe, well, we have her now,
And muſt diſpoſe her. Enter Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Hang both for two blind buzzards, here's a Spade
Quickly or Ile call the neighbours.
There's no remedy,
Would the poor hung • y priſoners had this paſtie. Exeunt. Enter Iuſtice, and a Servant with a light.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Twas a ſtrange miſchance ſir.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Miſchance, ſaiſt? No twas happineſſe to me,
There's ſo much charge ſav'd, I have her portion,
Ile marry twenty more on ſuch conditions.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Did it not trouble you ſir,
To ſee her dead?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Not much, I thank my conſcience;
I was tormented till that happen'd, furies
Were in my brain to think my ſelf a Cuckold
At that time of the night:
When I come home, I charge you ſhut my doors,
Locks, bolts, and barres, are little enough to ſecure me.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why, and pleaſe you?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Fool to ask that queſtion;
To keep out women, I expect her mother
Will viſit me with her clamors, oh I hate
Their noiſe, and do abhorre the whole ſex heartily;
They are all walking Devils, Harpyes, I will ſtudy
A week together how to raile ſufficiently,
Upon e'm all, and that I may be furniſh'd,
Thou ſhalt buy all the railing Books and Ballads,
That Malice hath invented againſt women,
I will read nothing elſe, and practiſe 'em,
Till I grow fat with curſes.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: If youle go
To th'charge, let me alone to find you Books.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: They come neer us.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Whats that?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Where? hold up the Torch Knave.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Did you hear nothing, 'tis a—

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Why doſt make a ſtand?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Whats that?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Where, where, doſt ſee any thing?
We are hard by the Church-yard, and I was never
Valiant at midnight in ſ • ch i • kſome places;
They ſay Ghoſts walk ſometimes, hark, de'e hear nothing?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: No further, dig here, and lay her in quickly.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: VVhat light is that Boy, we ſhall be diſcover'd;
Set the Coffin up an end, and get behind me,
There's no avoiding.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: VVhere's that groan? I begin to be afraid.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: VVhat ſhall we do ſir?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: VVe are almoſt at home now, thou muſt go forward;
Perhaps 'twas my imagination.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Tis he?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I know him too, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Oh ſir, a Ghoſt, the very Ghoſt of Miſtreſſe B • ide,
I have no power to runne away.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Curſed Ghoſt, bleſſe me, preſerve me,
I doe command thee what ſo ere thou art,
I doe conjure thee leave me; doe not fright me;
If thou beeſt a divell vexe me not ſo ſoone,
If thou beeſt
The ſpirit of my wife.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: Thy wife.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I ſhall be tormented.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Thy abus'd wife, that cannot peaceably
Enjoy her death, thou haſt an evill conſcience.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Ikow it

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Among thy other ſinnes which blacke thy ſoule,
Call to thy minde thy vow made to another,
Whom thou haſt wrong'd, and make her ſatisfaction
Now I am dead, thou perjur'd man, or elſe
A thouſand black tormentors ſhall purſue thee,
Vntill thou leape into eternall flames;
Where gold which thou adoreſt here on earth
Melted, the Fiends ſhall powre into thy throate;
For this time paſſe; goe home and thinke upon me.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: There are more ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Thanke you deare wife,
Ile beſtow twentie nobles of a Tombe for thee,
Thou ſhalt not walke and catch cold after death. They goe Backward in.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: So, ſo, they'r gone, twas my ingenious raſcal:
But how doſt know he made vowes to another?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I over-heard the women talke to night on't;
But now lets loſe no time ſir, pray lets bury
This Gen lewoman, where's my Miſtreſſe? Enter Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Here I durſt not tarry.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: we ha ſo coſen'd the old forty i' • h hundred,
And the devill hinder him not, hee'le goe a pilgrimage;
But come, about our buſineſſe, ſet her downe agen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Shee groanes, ha.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Agen, ſhe ſtirres.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Lets fly, or elſe we ſhall be torne in peeces.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And you be good at that, bury your ſelfe,
Or let the Sexton take ye for his fee,
Away boy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am very cold, dead cold;
Where am I? What's this? a Coffin? where have I been?
Mercy defend me: Ha, I doe remember
I was betrai'd, and ſwounded; my heart akes,
I am wondrous hungry too, dead bodies eate not;
Sure I was meant for buriall, I am frozen;
Death, 'like a cake of Ice dwells round about me,
Darkneſſe ſpreads o're the world too, where? what path?
Beſt providence direct me. Exit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: THou art the moſt unfortunate fellow;

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Why Aunt what have I done?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: The moſt malicious varlet,
Thy wicked head never at reſt, but hammering,
And haching h • lliſh things, and to no purpoſe,
So thou maiſt have thy baſe will.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Why doe you raile thus?
Cannot a ſcurvy accident fall out,
But I muſt be at one end on't?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou art at both ends.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Cannot young ſullen wenches play the fools,
And marry, and die, but I muſt be the agent?
All that I did (and if that be an injury,
Let the world judge it) was but to perſwade her,
(And as I take it) I was bound to it too,
To make the reverend coxecombe her husband Cuckold:
What elſe could I adviſe her, was there harme i' this?
You are of yeares, and have runne through experience,
Would you be content if you were young agen,
To have a continuall cough grow to your pillow,
A rottenneſſe, that vaults are perfumes to
Hang in youre roofe, and like a fogge infect you;
Anointed hammes to keepe his hinges turning
Reck ever in your noſe, and twenty night caps,
With twenty ſeveral ſweats.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Some Jew, ſome Juſtice,
A thouſand heathen ſmels to ſay truth Madam,
And would you mellow my young pretty Miſtreſſe
In ſuch a miſ-ken?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sirra,
Where's the body of my Girle?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I know not,
I am no Conjurer, you may look the body,
I was like to be ſtoln away my ſelf, the Spirit
Had like to ha ſurpris'd me in the ſhape of a woman,
Of a young woman, and you know thoſe are dangerous.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: So had I Madam, ſimply though I ſtand here,
I had been raviſh'd too: I had twenty Spirits
In every corner of the houſe a Fiend met me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You lie like raskals,
Was Miſtreſſe Newlove ſuch a Spirit ſir
To fright your worſhip;
Well, I diſcharge you ſir, ye'are now at libertie,
Live where you pleaſe, and do what pranks you fancy,
You know your ſubſtance, though you are my Nephew,
I am no way bound ſir to protect your miſchief;
So fare you well.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Farewell good Aunt, I thank you,
Adi • w honeſt Nick, the devil if he have power,
Will perſecute your old bones, for this marriage,
Farewel Miſtreſſe Win.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: And ſhall we part with dry lips;
Shall we that have been fellow devils together
Flench for an old womans fart?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Tis a fine time a night too, but we muſt part Nick.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Shall we never ring again? ne're toſſe the tenor,
And roul the changes in a Cup of Claret?
You ſhall not want what ere I lay my hands on,
As I am ſure Automedon the Coachman,
Shall be diſtributed; bear up, I ſay, hang ſorrow,
Give me that bird abroad that lives at pleaſure,
Sam the Butle • s true, the Cook a reverend Trojan,
The Faulkner ſhall ſell his Hawkes, and ſwear they were rotten,
There be ſome wandring ſpoons, that may be met with,
Ile pawn a Coach horſe, peace, utter no ſentences.
The harneſſe ſhall be us'd in our warres alſo;
Or ſhall I drive her) tell me but your will now,
Say but the word) over ſome rotten bridg,
Or by a Marle pit ſide, ſhe may ſlip in daintily,
Let me alone for my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No, no, farewel Toby,
Farewel ſpinie Nicholas, no ſuch thing,
There be wayes i'the world, if you ſee me
A day or two hence, may be weel'le crack a quart yet,
And pull a bell, commend to the houſhold;
Nay, cry not Toby 'twill make thy head giddy.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Sweet Maſter Wildbrain • .

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No more Toby, go, the times may alter—
But where's the coarſe of my dead coſen,
(If ſhe be dead) I hop'd 'thad but diſſembled
That ſits heavy here: Toby, honeſt Toby,
Lend me thy Lanthorn, I forgot 'twas dark,
I had need look to my wayes now.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Take a lodging with me to night in the Stable,
And ride away to morrow with one of the horſes
Next your heart, pray do.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No, good night good neighbour Toby, I will wander,
I ſcorn to ſubmit my ſelf, ere I have rambled,
But whether, or with what, that's more material;
No matter, and the worſt come it is but ſtealing,
And my Aunt won'ot ſee me hang'd for her own credit,
And farewel in a halter coſts me nothing. Exit. Enter Hartlove.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The night, and all the evils the night covers,
The Goblins, Hagges, and the black ſpawne of darkneſſe,
Cannot fright me, no death, I dare thy cruelty.
For I am weary both of life and light too;
Keep my wits heaven, they ſay ſpirits appear
To melancholly minds, and the graves open,
I would fain ſee the fair Maria's ſhadow,
But ſpeak unto her ſpirit ere I dyed,
But ask upon my knees a mercy from her;
I was a villain, but her wretched Kinſman,
That ſet his plot, ſhall with his heart blood ſatisfie
Her injur'd life and honor, what lights this? Enter Wildbrain with a Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: It is but melancholy walking thus;
The Tavern doors are baracado'd too,
Where I might drink till morn in expectation;
I cannot meet the Watch neither; nothing in
The likeneſſe of Conſtable, whom I might
In my diſtreſſe abuſe, and ſo be carried,
For want of other lodging, to the Counter.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Tis his voyce, Fate, I thanke thee.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Ha, who's that, and thou beeſt a man ſpeak?
Franke Heartlove, then I bear my deſtinies,
Thou art the man of all the world I wiſh'd for;
My Aunt has turn'd me out a doores, ſhe has,
At this unchriſtian houre, and I doe walke,
Me thinks, like Guido Faux with my darke Lanthorn,
Stealing to ſet the towne a fire; ith' country
I ſhould be tane for William o' the Wiſpe,
Or Robin Good fellow, and how doſt Frank?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: The worſe for you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Come, thar' • a foole, art going to thy lodging?
Ile lie with thee to night, and tell thee ſtories,
How many devills we ha met withal;
Our houſe is haunted Franke, whole legions,
I ſaw fiftie for my ſhare.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Didſt not fright e'm?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: How, fright e'm? no they frighted me fufficiently.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Thou hadſt wickedneſſe enough to make them ſtare,
And be afraid o'thee, malicious devil;
And draw thy ſword, for by Marias ſoule;
I will not let thee ſcape to do more miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Thou art mad, what doſt meane?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: To kill thee, nothing elſe will eaſe my anger,
The injury is freſh, I bleede with all,
Nor can that word expreſſe it, there's no peace in't,
Nor muſt it be forgiven but in death;
Therefore call up thy valour if thou'ſt any,
And ſummon up thy ſpirits to defend thee;
Thy heart muſt ſuffer for thy damn'd practiſes,
Againſt thy noble coſen, and my innocence.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Hold, heare a word; did I doe any thing
But for your good, that you might have her,
That in that deſperate time I might redeeme her,
Although with ſhew of loſſe.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Out ugly villaine,
Fling on her the moſt hated name of Whore
To the worlds eye, and face it out in courteſie,
Bring him to ſee't and make me drunke to attempt it. Enter Maria.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I heare ſome voyces this way.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: No more, if you can pray, doe it as you fight.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What new frights oppoſe me? I have heard that tongue.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Tis my fortune,
You could not take me in a better time ſir,
I ha nothing to loſe, but the love I lent thee,
My life my ſword protect.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I know'em both, but to prevent their ruines,
Muſt not diſcover—ſtay men moſt deſperate;
The miſchiefe you are forward to commit
Will keepe me from my grave, and tie my ſpirit
To endleſſe troubles elſe.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Ha, tis her Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Heare me both, each wound you make
Runnes through my ſoule, and is a new death to me,
Each threatning danger will affright my reſt;
Looke on me Hartlove, and my kinſman view me;
Was I not late in my unhappy marriage,
Sufficient miſerable? full of all misfortunes?
But you muſt adde with your moſt impious angers
Unto my ſleeping duſt this inſolence?
Would you teach time to ſpeake eternally
Of my diſgraces; make Records to • eep'em,
Keep them in braſs? fight then, and kill my honor;
Fight deadly both, and let your bloody ſwords,
Through my reviv'd, and reeking infamy
(That never ſhall be purg'd) finde your owne ruines:
Hartlove, I lov'd thee once, and hop'd again
In a more bleſſed love to meet thy ſpirit,
If thou kil'ſt him, thou art a murtherer,
And murther ſhall never inherit heaven:
My time is come, my concealed grave expects me,
Farewel, and follow not, your feet are bloody,
And will pollute my peace: I hope they are melted,
This is my way ſure. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Stay bleſſed ſoul.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: VVould ſhe had come ſooner, and ha ſav'd ſome blood.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Doſt bleed?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Yes certainly, I can both ſee and feel it.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Now I well hope it is not dangerous;
Give me thy hand, as honor guides me,
Ile know thee again. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I thank thee heartily;
I know not where to get a Surgeon;
This viſion troubles me, ſure ſhe is living,
And I was fooliſh blind, I could not find it;
I bleed apace ſtill, and my heart grows heavy,
If I go far I faint, Ile knock at this houſe,
They may be charitable, would t'were perfect day. Enter Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Tis not he? What would you ſir?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I would crave a little reſt Lady,
And for my hurts ſome Surgerie, I am a Gentleman
That Fortune of a fight—

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: A handſome Gentleman,
Alas he bleeds, a very handſome Gentleman,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: A ſweet young wench, beſhrow my heart a fair one;
Fortune has made me ſome recompence,

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Pray come in; the air is hurtful for you
Pray let me lead you, Ile have a bed for you preſently,
Ile be your Surgeon too, alas ſweet Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I feel no hurts, the morning comes too faſt now.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Soſtly I beſeech you. Exit. Enter Lady and Toby.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: He is not up yet Madam, what mean't you
To come forth ſo early?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You block head;
Yo • r eyes are ſow'd up ſtill, they cannot ſee
When it is day: oh my poor Maria;
Where be the women?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: They ſaid they would follow us.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He ſhall not laugh thus at my miſery,
And kill my child, and ſteal away her body,
And keep her Portion too.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Let him be hang'd for't,
You have my voice.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Theſe women not come yet?
A ſonne in law, Ile keep a Conjurer,
But Ile find out his knavery.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Do, and Ile help him.
And if he were here this whip ſhould conjure him,
Here's a capias, and it catch hold on's breech,
Ide make him ſoon beleeve the Devil were there.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: An old Uſurer.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: He married the mony, thats all he lookt for,
For your daughter, let her ſink or ſwim.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ile ſwim him;
This is his houſe, I wonder they ſtay thus,
That we might raiſe him out on's wits.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: They'le come,
Fear not Madam, and bring clappers with 'em
Or ſome have loſt their old wont, I have heard
No diſparagement to your Ladiſhip, ſome o'their tongues
Like Tom a Lincolne three miles off.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh fie,
How tedious are they?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: What and we loſt no time,
You and I ſhall make a ſhift to begin with him,
And tune our Inſtruments, till the conſort come
To make up the full noiſe, Ile knock.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Who's that? rapt ſo ſawcily?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Tis I, Toby, come down, or elſe we'le fetch you down,
Alas, this is but the Sauncebell, here's a Gentlewoman
Will ring you another peal, come down, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Some new fortifications, look to my doors,
Put double barres, I will not have her enter,
Nor any of her Tribe, they come to terrefie me:
Keep out her tongue too if you can.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I hear you,
And I will ſend my tongue up to your worſhip,
The Eccho of it ſhall flye o're the ſtreete;
My Daughter, that thou killedſt with kindneſſe (Jew)
That thou betrayedſt to death, thou double Jew,
And after ſtol'ſt her body.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Iew's too good for him.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I defie you both;
Thy daughter plaid the villaine and betray'd me:
Betray'd my honor.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Honor, Raſcal,
And let that bear an action, Ile try it with thee,
Honor?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Oh Reprobate!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou muſtie Iuſtice,
Buy an honourable halter, and hang thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: A worſhipful ropes end is too good for him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Get honor that way, thou wot die a dogge elſe.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Come and be whipt firſt.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Where is her Portion. Enter Nurſe and women.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Where Ile keepe it ſafely.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Traitor, thou ſhalt not keep it.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: More of the kennel? put more bolts to'th doores there,
And arme your ſelves, hell is broke looſe upon us.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: I am glad y'are come, weele blow the houſe down.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh Nurſe, I haue ſuch cauſe—

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Villaine, viper, although you had no cauſe, we are bound
To helpe.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Yes, and beleeve, we come not here to examine,
And if you pleaſe weele fire the houſe

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Call the Conſtable.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: A charitable motion, fire is comfortable.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No no, wele only let him know ou • minds,
We will commit no outrage, he's a Lawyer,

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Give me my musket.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Where's my daughters body,
That I may bury it?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Speak, or weele bury thee.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Alive weele bury thee, ſpeak old Iniquitie.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Bury him alive by all meanes for a teſtimony.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Their voyces make my houſe reel, oh for Officers,
I am in a dreame, thy daughters ſpirit
Walkes a nights, and troubles all the neighbours;
Goe hire a Conjurer, Ile ſay no more.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: The Law ſhall ſay more,

sp.speaker: Wo. Nur.
sp.l: We are witneſſes,
And if thou beeſt not hang'd— Enter Lurcher, and Boy.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Buy a book of good manners,
A ſhort Book of good manners.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Buy a ballad, a ballad of the maid was got with child

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: That might ha beene my caſe laſt night,
Ile ha't what ere it coſt me.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: A ballad of the witches hang'd at Ludlow.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: I will have that too;
There was an Aunt of mine, I thinke amongſt e'm,
I would be glad to heare her Teſtament.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A new book of women,

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The thunders laid, how they ſtare at him

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A new book of fooles, a ſtrange book,
Very ſtrange fooles.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Ile owe thee a good turne what e • 'e thou art.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A book of walking ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: That I like not.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Nor I, they walk'd me the fooles morris.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A book of wicked women.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Thats well thought on.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Of rude malicious women, of proud women,
Of ſcolding, women, we ſhall nere get in.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A ballad of wrong'd Maides.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ile buy that.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A little very little book.
Of good and godly women, a very little one,
So little, you may put it in a nutſhel.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: with a ſmall print, that no body can read it.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Peace ſirra, or Ile teare your books.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Open the doore, and let him in, I love him

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A book of evil Magiſtrates.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I marry, dee hear that Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And their eviller wives,
That weare their places in their peticotes.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Dee you hear that Lady.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A book new printed, againſt Playing,
Dancing, Masking, May-poles; a zealous Brothers book,
And full of Fables.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Another book of women, of mad women,
Women that were born in March. Exit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Are you got in?
We would ha pul'd your knaves hide elſe; this fellow
Was ſent to abuſe us, but we ſhall have time
To talk more with this Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Farewel Madam, as you like this come viſit me agen,
You and your treble ſtrings, now ſcold your hearts out—

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Shall he carry it thus away?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Go to the Judg, and what you'le have us ſwear—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I thank ye heartily,
Ile keep that for the laſt, I will go home,
And leave him to his Conſcience for a while,
If it ſleep long, Ile wake it with a vengeance. Exit. Enter Servants.
What book has he given thee?
A dainty book, a book of the great Navy,
Of fifteen hundred ſhips of Canon proof,
Built upon Whales to keep their keels from ſinking;
And Dragons in'em, that ſpit fire ten mile;
And Elephants that carry goodly caſtles.
Doſt thou beleeve it?
Shall we not beleeve books in Print?
I have John Taylors book of Hempſeed too,
Which for two lines I hapned on by chance,
I reverence.
I prethee what are they?
They are ſo put upon the time, as if
He ſtudied to anſwer the late Hiſt • iomaſtix,
Talking of change and transformations,
That wittily, and learnedly he bangs him,
So many a Puritans ruffe, though ſtarched in Print,
Be turn'd to Paper, and a Play writ in't:
A Play in the Puritans ruf • e? Ile buy his Works for't,
And conſute Horace with a Water Poet:
What haſt there a ballad too?
This is a pecce of Poetry indeed; He ſings; Juſtice cries within.
What noiſe is that?
Some cry ith' ſtreets; prethee ſing on. Sing again.
Agen, doſt not hear? 'tis ith' houſe certainly?
Tis a ſtrange noiſe? and has a tang o'the Juſtice.
Lets ſee? Exit.

l.hi: Enter the Servants bringing in their Maſter bound and gag'd.

sp.l: Untie his feet, pull out his gag, he will choak elſe;
What deſperate rogues were theſe.
Give him freſh air.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: I will never ſtudy books more;
I am undone, theſe villains have undone me.
Rifled my Desk, they have undone me learnedly;
A fire take all their books, Ile burn my Study:
Where were you raſcals when the villains bound me,
You could not hear.
He gave us books ſir, dainty books to buſie us;
And we were reading in that which was the Brewhouſe;
A great way off, we were ſinging ballads too,
And could not hear.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: This was a precious theef,
A ſubtle trick to keep my ſervants ſafe.
What ha you loſt ſir?

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: They ranſack'd all before my face, and threatned
To kill me, if I congh'd, they have a chain,
My rings, my box of caſting gold, my pu • ſe too,
They rob'd me miſerably; but that which moſt grieves me,
They took away ſome writings; twas a Rogue
That knew me, and ſet on by the old Lady,
I will indite her for't.
Shall we purſue 'em?

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Run, run, curſed raskals,
I am out of my wits, let not a creature in,
No not with neceſſaries.
We ſhall be ſtarv'd.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Ile buy my meat at window, as they paſſe by;
I wonot truſt my Scrivenor, he has books too;
And bread Ile ha ſlung up; I charge ye all
Burn all the books i'th houſe.
Your little Prayer book?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Ile never pray agen, ile have my doores
Made up, nothing but walls, and thicke ones too;
No ſound ſhall tempt me a gen, remember I
Have for ſwoare bookes,
If you ſhould be call'd to take your oath.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I will forſwear all oaths, rather than ſee
A thing but in the likeneſſe of a booke:
And I were condemn'd, Ile rather chuſe to hang,
Than read agen; come in, and ſearch all places,
They may be about the houſe, were the doores lock'd?
But the keyes in 'em, and if they be gone,
They could not want wit to lock us in ſir.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Never was man ſo miſerably undone,
I would loſe a limbe to ſee their rogueſhips totter. Exeunt. Enter Lady and Nurſe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thy brothers daughter, ſaiſt, and born in Wales?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: I have long time deſired to ſee her, and I hope
Your Ladiſhip will not be offended.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No, no.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: I ſhould be happy if ſhe might be ſerviceable
To you Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Beſhrow me, but at firſt, ſhe took me much,
Is ſhe not like Maria? ſetting aſide
Her language very like her, and I love her
The better for't, I prethee call her hither,
She ſpeakes feat Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Why Guennith, Guennith, du hummah Guenneth;
She is courſe Madam, after her country guiſe,
And were ſhe in fine clothes—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ile have her handſome: Enter Maria.
What part of Wales were you borne in?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: In Abehundis Madams.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: She ſpeakes that name in Welſh, which we call Brecknocke

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What can you do?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Her was toe many tings in Walls, know not the faſhion in Londons? her was milk the Cowes, make ſeeze and butters, and ſpinne very well the Welſh freeze, her was Cooke to te Mountain cots, and ſing very fine prittiſh tunes was mage good ales and breds, and her know to dance on Sundayes, marge you now Madams.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A pretty innocence, I doe like her infinitely, Nurſe,
And if I live— Enter Servant.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Here is Mr. Hartlove, Madam come to ſee you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas poore Gentleman, prethee admit him. Enter Hartlove and Gent.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Madam, I am come to take my laſt leave.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How ſir?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Of all my home affections, and my friends,
For the intereſt you had once in Maria,
I would • cquaint you when I leave the kingdome.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Would there were any thing in my poore power
That might divert your will, and make you happy;
I am ſure I haue wrong'd her too, but let your pardon
Aſſure me you are charitable; ſhee's dead
Which makes us both ſad: What do you look on?
The likeſt face—

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Pleſſe us awle, why does that ſentilman make ſuch unders and mazements at her, I know her not.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Be not offended maid.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How the Wench bluſhes, ſhee repreſents Marias loſſe to him.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Will the ſentilman hurt her, pray you be her defences, was haue mad phiſnomies, is her troubled with Lunaticks in her praine pans, bleſſe us awle.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Where had you this face?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Her faces be our none I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Ha,
sp.l: I wonot hurt you, all the lineaments
That built Maria up; all thoſe ſpringing beauties
Dwell on this thing, change but her tongue I know her:
Let me ſee your hand.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Du Guin, was never theeves, and robberies; here is no ſindge in her hands warrant her.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Truſt me, the ſelf-ſame white,
And ſoftneſſe, prethee ſpeak our Engliſh Dialect.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Haleggs? what does her ſpeage hard urds to her, to make poore Guennith ridicles, was no mannerly ſentilman to abuſe her

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: By the love,
That everlaſting love I bare Maria—

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Maria, her name was Guenith, and good names, was poore elſe, oman maide, her have no fine kanags to madge her trickſie, yet in her owne cuntries was held a fine enſe her can tels her, and honeſt enſe too, marg you dat now, her can keepe her little legges cloſe enough warrant her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How pretily this anger ſhewes.
She gabbles innocently.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Madam farewell, and all good fortune dwell w'ee,
With me my owne affections; farwell maid,
Faire gentle maide.
She ſighes.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Du cat a whee.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I cannot goe, theres ſomwhat calls me backe.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Poore Franke,
How gladly would I entertaine thy love,
And meet thy worthy flame, but ſhame forbids, me:
sp.p: If pleaſe her Ladyſhip dwell here with Guenneth, and learne to ſpinne and card ull, to mage flannells, and linſeyes ulſeis, ſall tawgco'd urds to her Ladyſhips urſhips for her. The teares flow from him,
sp.l: The teares of true affection, woe is me,
O curſed love that glories in maids miſeries,
And true mens broken hearts.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas I pitty him, the wench is rude, and knowes you not, forgive her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Wyne your nyes pray you, though was porne in Walls 'mong craggy rocks, and mountaines yet heart is ſoft, looke you, hur can weepe too, when hur ſee men mage prinie teares and lamentations.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: How hard ſhe holds me?
Juſt as Maria did, weepes the ſame drops,
Now as I have a living ſoule, her ſight too;
What ſhall I thinke, is not your name Maria,
If it be not, delude me with ſo much charity
To ſay it is.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Vpon her life, you was mightie deal in love with ſome • odies, your pale ſeekes and hollow nyes, and pantings upon • er poſome, know very well, becauſe looke you, her thinke her honeſt ſentilman, you ſall call her Maria.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Good Madam, thinke not ill I am thus ſawcie,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Oh no ſir, be you not angry with the wench.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am moſt pleas'd.
Lets interrupt him, hee'l be mad outright elſe.
Obſerve a little more.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Would I could in your language beg a kiſſe,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: If her have neceſſities of a kiſſe, looke you, dere is one in ſarities.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Let me ſuffer death,
If in my apprehenſion two twinnd cherries
Be more a kin, then her lips to Marias;
And if this harſh illuſion would but leave her,
She were the ſame, good Madam, ſhall I have
Your conſent now.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: To what?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: To give this Virgin to me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: She's not mine, this is her Kinſwoman,
And has more power to diſpoſe; alas, I pitty him.
Pray gentleman prevaile with him to goe;
More that I wiſh his comfort than his abſence.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You have beene alwayes kind to me, will you
Denie me your faire Couſen.

sp.speaker: Nu.
sp.l: 'Twere fit you firſt obtain'd her own conſent.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: He is no friende that wiſhes my departure,
I doe not trouble you.
Tis not Maria.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Her ſhadow is enough, Ile dwell with that,
Perſue your owne wayes, ſhall we live together;

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: If her will come tomorrow and tauge to her, her will tell her more of her meanings, and then if her be melancholy, her will ſing her a Welch ſong too, to make her merries, but Guenith was very honeſt; her was never love but one ſentleman, and he was beare her great teale of goodills too, was marry one day S. Davy her give her five paire of white gloves, if her will dance at her weddings.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: All I am worth,
And all my hopes, this ſtrange voyce would forſake her,
For then ſhe ſhud be—prethee ſtay a little,
Harke in thine • are, diſſemble not, but tell me,
And ſave my life; I know you are Maria:
Speke but as) doe ten words to confirme me;
You have an Engliſh ſoule, do not diſguiſe it
From me with theſe ſtrange accents—She pinch'd hard
Againe, and ſigh'd.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What ailes the Wench? Exit.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Why, Gunith.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: She's gone too,
Come leave this dreame.

sp.speaker: Ha
sp.l: A dreame? I thinke ſo;
But 'twas a pleaſing one, now Ile obey,
And forget all theſe wonders, lead the way. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: HOneſt Toby?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Sweet Mr. Wildbrain,—I am glad I ha met we yee.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Why did my aunt ſend for me?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Your Aunt's a mortal, and thinkes not on you
For ought I can perceive.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Is my Coſen alive agen?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Neither, and yet we doe not heare
That ſhe's buried.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: What ſhould make thee glad then?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: What ſhould make me glad? have I not cauſe,
To ſee your Princely body well, and waike thus,
