Looke blith and bonny, and your wardrobe whole ſtill?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: The Caſe is cleare, and I ha found a Mine;
A perfect Indie, ſince my Aunt caſheer'd me;
What think'ſts of this?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Oh delicate bells.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Thou putteſt me in minde,
We are to ring anon, I mean to ſend for thee;
Meere me at the old Pariſh Church.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Say no more.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: When thy Lady is a bed, we ha conſpir'd
A midnight peale for joy.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: If I faile hang mei'th bell ropes.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: And how? and how does my Aunt?

sp.speaker: To
sp.l: She's up to'th eares in Law;
I doe ſo whirle her to the Counſellors chambers,
And backe againe, and bounce her for more money,
And too again, I know not what they doe with her;
But ſhe's the merrieſt thing among theſe Lawdrivers;
And in their ſtudies halfe a day together;
If they doe get her with Magna Charta, ſhe ſweares,
By all the abilitie of her old body,
She will ſo claw the Juſtice, ſhe will ſell
The tiles of the houſe ſhe vowes, and ſacke out o'th cellar,
(That ſhe worſhips to Idolatry) but ſhele hang him.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I would ſhe could: but hark thee honeſt Toby.
If a man haue a Miſtreſſe, may we not
With out my Aunts leave, borrow now and then
A coach to tumble in, toward the Exchange,
And ſo forth?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: A Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: She may be thine when we are married.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Command, Ile carry you both in pompe;
And let my Lady go a foot a Law-catching,
And exerciſe her cornes: where is ſhe Maſter Iohn?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Shat ſee her.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Shall we ring for her?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: And drinke her health.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Drinke ſtiffely for five hours.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Weele drinke fifteen.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: To night? we will ha twenty torches then,
And through the ſtreet drive on triumphantly;
Triumphantly weele drive, by my Ladyes doore,
As I am a Chriſtian, Coachman, I will rattle you
And urine in her porch and ſhe ſhall feare me:
If you ſay more, I ſhall runne mad outright,
I will drinke ſack and ſurfeit inſtantly;
I know not where I am now. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Hold for thy buttons ſake, the knave's tranſported.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Honeſt Tom, how thrives the fellonious world with thee now?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You looky and talke as you were much exalted.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: That't i'th right Tom. Ile tell thee firſt,
I ha ſhooke off my Aunt, and yet I live ſtill,
And drink, and ſing; her houſe had like to ha ſpoil'd me;
I keepe no houres now;
Nor need any falſe key
To the old womans Cabinets, I ha money
Vpon my word, and pawne no oathes toth' Buttler;
No matrimoniall proteſtations
For ſacke poſſets to the chambermaid,
I praiſe my Fate, there be more wayes toth' wood Tom.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Prethee releaſe my wonder.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Ile encreaſe it, wipe thine eyes,
Here is a chaine worth mony and ſome man had it,
A fooliſh Diamond, and other trifles—

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The very ſame, Oh Gipſey! Infidell!
All that I ſweat, and ventur'd my necke for,
He has got already; who would truſt a ſtrumpet.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: This? This is nothing to what I poſſeſſe
At home.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What home?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A houſe that ſhall be nameleſſe;
The Miſtreſſe of it mine too, ſuch a peece
For fleſh and blood, added to that ſo loving—

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Is ſhe married?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I know not, nor I care not;
But ſuch a prize, ſo mounting, ſo delicious,
Thou wilt runne mad, Ile tell thee more hereafter,

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.l: Nay prethee a word more.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I tooke no paines to finde out all this Paradiſe,
My deſtiny threw me upon't ith' darke, I found it
Wanting a lodging too.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No old acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Never, never ſaw her;
But theſe things happen not in every age,
I cannot ſtay, If thou wilt meete anon
At my owne randevow, thou knoweſt the Tavern,
Weele ſup together, after that a company
Of mery lads have made a match to ring.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You keepe youre exerciſe, i'the old Church?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No other,
There is no muſicke to the bells, we wo'd
Have bonefires if we durſt, and thou wo'd come
It ſhall coſt thee nothing Tom, hang pilfering,
And keepe me company, in time I may
Shew thee my Wench too.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I cannot promiſe; but you will be there?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Weele toſſe the bells, and make the ſteeple
Rore boy, but come to ſupper then.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My hand, and expect me:
Yes I will come or ſend, and to ſome purpoſe;
Art come boy?
sp.stage: Enter Boy with Gowne, Beard, and Conſtables ſtaffe.
sp.l: Excellent, Knave, how didſt thou purchaſe theſe?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: The ſtaffe I ſtole laſt night from a ſleeping Conſtable;
The reſt I borrowed by my acquaintance with
The players boyes; you were beſt to loſe no time ſir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So, ſo, helpe boy, tis very well, doe I not looke
Like one that breakes the Kings peace with authoritie?
You know your charge, prepare things hanſomely,
My diligent boy, and leave me to my office,

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: There wants nothing already; but I fly ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Now Fortune prove no ſlut, and Ile adore thee.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Whoſe there? Knocks.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A friend wo'd ſpeake with Maſter Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I am the Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My Maſter is not at leaſure to heare buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: How? Not at leaſure to doe the King ſervice;
Take heede what you ſay ſir; I know his worſhip,
If he know my buſineſſe, would no excuſe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: You muſt goe to another Juſtice, Ile aſſure
My Maſter is not well in health.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I know not,
But if your worſhipful be not at leaſure
To do himſelfe a benefit, I am gone ſir,
An infinite benefit, and the State ſhall thanke him for't;
Thanke him, and thinke on him too; I am an Officer,
And know my place, but I doe love the Juſtice;
I honor any authoritie above me:
Beſide, he is my neighbour, and I worſhip him.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: You have no bookes, not ballads, Mr Conſtable,
About you?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What ſhould I doe with bookes? does it become
A man of my place to underſtand ſuch matters?
Pray call your Maſter, if he pleaſe to follow me,
I ſhall diſcover to him ſuch a plot,
Shall get him everlaſting fame, Ile be hang'd for't
And he be not knighted inſtantly, and for reward
Have ſome of the malefactors lands Ile bring him too;
But I can not delay time. Within.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: A Conſtable ſir, would ſpeake about ſome buſineſſe,
He ſayes, will bring you fame, and mighty profit.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Pleaſe your worſhip, come downe, Ile make you happy;
The notabl'ſt peece of villany I have in hand ſir,
And you ſhall finde it out; I ha made choyce
To bring your worſhip to the firſt knowledge, and
Thanke me, as you finde the good on't afterwards.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What is it? Treaſon?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Tis little better, I can tell you, I have lodg'd.
A crew of the moſt rank and deſperate villaines:
They talke of robberies, and wayes they did'em;
And how they left men bound in their ſtudies.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: With bookes and ballads?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: That ſir? that, and murders,
And thouſand knaveries more, tha'te very rich ſir,
In mony, jewels, chaines, and a hundered more
Devices.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Happy, happy Conſtable, I met yee
At the back doore, get ready knaves.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Not a man I beſeech you,
I have privately appointed ſtrength about me,
They cannot ſtart, your men would breede ſuſpition;
All my deſire is you would come alone;
That you might have the hope of the enterpriſe,
That you might heare e'm firſt, and then proceed ſir,

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I come, I come.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Tis very well. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Keep all my doors faſt, 'tis ſomething late.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So, ſo, and pleaſe your worſhip I direct you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: My Maſter ſtayes, I doubt his lime-twigges catch not,
If they do, all's provided; but I all
This while forget my own ſtate, fair Maria
Is certainly alive, I met her in
Another habit, with her Nurſe, 'twas ſhe:
There is ſome trick in't, but when this is over,
Ile find it out, this project for the Uſurer
May have good effect; however 'twill be ſport
To mortifie him a litle; Enter Lurcher.
He's come without him:
Have you fail'd ſir?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Proſper'd? my little Ingineer; away,
He is ith' next room, be not you ſeen, ſirra. Exit.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: The pitfall's ready, never Juſtice
Was caught in ſuch a nooze, ere he get out,
He ſhall run through a ſcouring purgatory,
Shall purge him to the quick, 'tis night already. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Come ſoftly, yet ſir ſoftly, are you not weary?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Th'aſt brought me into a melancholy place,
I ſee no creature.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: This is, ſir, their den
Where they ſuppoſe themſelves ſecure, I am faint,
With making haſt; but I muſt be thus troubled,
And therefore never go without a cordial; Seems to drink.
Without this I ſhould die;
How it refreſhes me
Already? will't pleaſe your worſhip? I might have had
The manners to ha let you drink before me;
Now am I Iuſty.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: 'Twas a good taſte.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Taſte? how dee find the vertue, nay ſir ſpare it not:
My wife has the receit, do's it not ſtir
Your worſhips body? when you come to examine,
'Twill make you ſpeak like thunder

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Hoy he.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I works already.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Is there never a chair, I was wearier than I thought,
But who ſhall we have to take 'em Mr. Conſtable?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Let me alone, when I but give the watch-word
We will have men enough to ſurpriſe an Army.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: I begin to be ſleepy; what, haſt a chair?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: They do not dream of us, 'tis early riſing;
Care, care, and early riſing, common-wealths men
Are ever ſubjects to the nods; ſitdown ſir,
A ſhort nap is not much amiſs; ſo, ſo, he's faſt;
Faſt as a fiſh ith' net, he has winking powder
Shall work upon him to our wiſh, remove him,
Nay, we may cut him into collops now
And he n're feel; have you prepar'd the vault ſirra?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Yes, yes, ſir, every thing in's place.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: When we have plac'd him, you and I boy
Muſt about another project hard by, his potion
Will bind him ſure enough till we return,
This villany weighs mainly, but weele purge ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: They ring a wager, and I muſt deal juſtly, ha boyes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Doſt hear'em, ha • d, theſe be the Ringers?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Are you ſure the fame?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Or my directions fail;
The coaſt is clear:
How the bells go? how daintily they tumble?
And me thinks they ſeem to ſay; Fine fools Ile fit you?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: excellent agen, good boyes—oh that was nought.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Be you conce •• 'd by any means yet; hark,
They ſtop, I hope thei'le to'o • gon, cloſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A palpable knock.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: 'Twas none.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Be judg'd by the Sexton then,
If I have ears.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: A knock, a knock, a groſs one.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Carman your gallon of wine, you ring moſt impiouſly,
Art thou of the worſhipful company of the Knights oth' Weſt,
And handle a bell with no more dexterity;
You think you are in Thames ſtreet
Juſtling the carts: oh a clean hand's a jewel.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Good ſpeed to your good exerciſe.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Y'are welcome.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I come ſir from a Gentleman, and neighbour hard by,
One that loves your muſick well.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: He may have more on't,
Handle a bell, as you were haling timber;
Groſs, groſs, and baſe, abſurd,

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Ile mend it next peal.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: To intreat a knowledge of you, whether it be
By the Ear you ring thus cunningly or by the Eye;
For to be plain, he has laid ten pounds upon't.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: But which way has he laid?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That your Ear guides you,
And not your Eye.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Has won, has won, the Ear's our onely inſtrument:

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: But how ſhall we be ſure on't.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Put all the lights out, to what end ſerve our Eyes then?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A plain Caſe.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You ſay true, 'tis a fine cunning thing to ring by th'ear ſure:
And can you ring ith' dark ſo?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: All night long boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: 'Tis wonderful, let this be certain Gentlemen,
And half his wager he allows among ye;
Iſt poſſible you ſhould ring ſo?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Poſſible. thou art a child, Ile ring when I am dead drunk
Out with the lights, no twinckling of a candle,
I know my rope too, as I know my noſe,
And can bang it ſoundly ith' dark, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Come let's confirm him ſtraight and win the wager. Exit.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Let me hear to ſtrengthen me;
And when y'ave rung Ile bring the money to you.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So, ſo, follow'em;
They ſhall have a cool reward, one hath gold of mine,
Good ſtore in's pocket, Ring.
But this will be reveng'd in a ſhort warning.
They are at it luſtily; hey, how wantonly
They ring away their cloaths, how it delights me;

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Here, here, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Haſt Wildbraines.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: His whole caſe ſir; I felt it out, and by the guards
This ſhould be the Coachmans, another ſuite too.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Away Boy, quickly now to the Uſurer,
His hour to wake approaches.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That once finiſh'd,
Youle give me leave to play ſir: here they come.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I am monſtrous weary.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Fie, how I ſwear? Reach me my cloak to cover me,
I run to oyl like a Porpiſe; 'twas a brave peal.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Let me light my candle firſt, then Ile wait on you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A very brave peal.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Carman, you came in cloſe now.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Sure 'tis paſt midnight.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: No ſtirring in the ſtreets I hear.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Walk further, was that a pillar? 'tis harder than my noſe.
Where's the Boy promis'd us five pound?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Room, I ſweat ſtill; come, come, my cloak,
I ſhall take cold.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Where lies it?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Here, here, and all our cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Where, where?

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Ith' the corner.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Is thy candle blind too, give me the bottle,
I can drink like a Fiſh now, like an Elephant.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Here are the corners, but here are no cloaths;
Yes, here is a cuffe.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: A cuffe? give me the candle,
Cuffes wo'not cover me—I ſmell the knavery.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Iſt come to a cuffe? my whole ſuit turned to a button?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Now am I as cold again as though 'twere Chriſtmas;
Cold with my fear, Ile never ring by the ear more.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: My new cloaths vaniſh'd?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: My all cloaths Toby.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Here's none.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Not one of my dragons wings left to adorn me,
Have I muted all my feathers?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Cheated by the ear; a plot to put out the candle;
I could be mad; my chain, my rings, the gold, the gold.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: The cold, the cold I cry, and I cry truly,
Not one ſleeve, nor a cape of a cloak to warm me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: What miſerable fools were we?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: We had e'en beſt, gentlemen,
Every man chuſe his rope again, and faſten it,
And take a ſhort turn to a better fortune
To be bawds to our miſeries, and put our own lights out?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Prethee Sexton lets have a fire at thy houſe,
A good fire, weele pay thee ſome way for't, I am ſtone cold.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Alas I pitty you, come quickly Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Sure I ha been in a dream, I had no Miſtreſs,
Nor gold, nor cloaths, but am a ringing raſcal.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Fellows in affliction, let's take hands all,
Now are we fit for tumblers.
sp.stage: Enter Lurcher and others, bringing in Algripe.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So, ſo, preſently his ſleep will leave him.
And wonder ſeize upon him,
Bid 'em within be ready.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: What ſound's this?
What horrid dinne? what diſmal place is this?
I never ſaw before, and now behold it;
But by the half light of a lamp, that burns here:
My ſpirits ſhake, tremble through my body;
Help, help,

l.hi: Enter two Furies with black tapers.

sp.l: Mercy, protect me, my ſoul quakes,
What dreadful apparitions! how I ſhudder!

sp.speaker: 1. 2. Fu.
sp.l: Algripe.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: What are you?
We are helhounds, helhounds, that have commiſſion From the Prince of darkneſs,
To fetch thy black ſoul to him.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Am I not alive ſtill?
Thou art, but we have brought thee inſtruments
Will quickly rid thy miſerable life, Stabbe,
Poyſon.
Hang thy ſelf, this choiſe is offer'd,
Thou canſt not hope for heaven; thy baſe ſoul is Loſt to all hope of mercy.
Quickly, quickly,
The torments cool.
And all the Fiends expect thee.
Come with us to that pit of endleſs horrour,
Or we will force thee.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh.
Groans are too late, ſooner the raviſher,
Whoſe ſoul is hurl'd into eternal froſt,
Stung with the force of twenty thouſand Winters,
To puniſh the diſtempers of his blood,
Shall hope to get from thence, then thou avoid
The certainty of meeting hell where he is.
Shall murderers be there for ever dying,
Their ſouls ſhot through with adders, torn on Engines,
Dying as many deaths for killing one,
Could any imagination number them,
As there be moments in eternity:
And ſhall that Juſtice ſpare thee, that haſt ſlain,
Murdered by thy extortion ſo many?

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Oh, oh.
Do execution quickly, or we'le carry thee alive to hell.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Gently, gentle devils, do not force me
To kill my ſelf, nor do not you do't for me;
O let me live, Ile make amends for all.
Tell us of thy repentance? perjur'd villain,
Pinch off his fleſh, he muſt be whipt, ſalted and whipt.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Oh miſery of miſeries!
Tear his accurſed limbs, to hell with him, ha.
A miſchief on that innocent face, away.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Malicious furies hence, choak not the ſeeds
Of holy penitence.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: This muſt be an Angel,
How at his preſence the fiends crawle away?
Here is ſome light of mercy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Be thou wiſe,
And entertain it, wretched, wretched man;
What poor defence hath all thy wealth been to thee?
What ſayes thy conſcience now?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Be my good Angel, here I promiſe thee,
To become honeſt, and renounce all villany;
Enjoyn me any pennance, Ile build Churches;
A whole City of Hoſpitals.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Take heed,
There is no dallying, nor are theſe impos'd.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Name any thing within my power, ſweet Angel;
And if I do not faithfully perform it,
Then whip me every day, burn me each minute,
Whole years together let me freeze to Iſicles.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Ith' number of thy foul oppreſſions;
Thou haſt undone a faithful Gentleman,
By taking forfeit of his land.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Young Lurcher,
I do confeſs.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: He lives moſt miſerable,
And in deſpair may hang or drown himſelf;
Prevent his ruine, or his blood will be
More ſin in thy account: haſt thou forgotten
He had a ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I do well remember it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Couldſt thou for Mammon break thy ſolemn vow,
Made once to that unhappy maid, that weeps
A thouſands tears a day for thy unkindneſs,
Was not thy faith contracted, and thy heart?
And couldſt thou marry another?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: But ſhe is dead,
And I will make true ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: What do inſtance theſe, that haſt been falſe
To all the world.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I know it, and will henceforth
Practiſe repentance, do not ſrown ſweet Angel;
I will reſtore all morgages, forſwear
Abominable Uſury, live chaſte;
For I have been wanton in my ſhroud, my age;
And if that poor innocent maid, I ſo abus'd,
Be living, I will marry her, and ſpend
My dayes to come religiouſly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I was commanded but a Meſſenger
To tell thee this, and reſcue thee from thoſe,
Whoſe malice would have drag'd thee quick to hell,
If thou abuſe this mercy and repent nor,
Double damnation will expect thee for it;
But if thy life be vertuous hereafter,
A bleſſedneſs ſhall reward thy good example,
Thy fright hath much diſtracted thy weak ſenſes,
D • ink of this viol, and renew thy ſpirits,
I ha done my office, think on't and be happy.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So, ſo, he gapes already, now he's faſt;
Thou haſt acted rarely; but this is not all;
Firſt, help to convey him out o'th vault.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You will diſpenſe with me now, as you promis'd ſir,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: We will make ſhift without thee, tha'ſt done well,
By our device this bondage may ſcape hell.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Didſt think Maria, this poor outſide, and
Diſſembling of thy voice could hide thee from
A mothers ſearching eye, though too much fear,
Leſt thou wert not the ſame, might blind a lover
That thought thee dead too; oh my dear Maria,
I hardly Kept my joyes in from betraying thee:
VVelcome again to life, we ſhall find out
The myſtery of thy abſence; conceale
Thy perſon ſtill, for Algripe muſt not know thee:
And exerciſe this pretty dialect;
If there be any courſe in Law to free thee,
Thou ſhalt not be ſo miſerable; be ſilent
Good Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: You ſhall not need to fear me Madam,
I do not love the uſuring Jew ſo well;
Beſide, 'twas my trick to diſguiſe her ſo.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Be not dejected Mall.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your care may comfort me;
But I deſpair of happineſs:
I dare not ſee him.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: VVeele withdraw.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I ſhall but grieve to ſee his paſſions too,
Since there's no poſſibility to relieve him.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: The world's a Labyrinth, where unguided men
Walk up and down to find their wearineſs;
No ſooner have we meaſured with much toil
One crooked path, with hope to gain our freedom,
But it betrays us to a new affliction;
What a ſtrange mockery will man become
Shortly to all the creatures?
Oh Mariah!
If thou beeſt dead, why does thy ſhadow fright me?
Sure 'tis becauſe I live; were I but certain
To meet thee in one grave, and that our duſt
Might have the priuiledge to mix in ſilence,
How quickly ſhould my ſoul ſhake off this burthen!
Thus far my wiſhes have ſucceſs, Ile loſe
No time: Sir, are not you call'd Mr. Hartlove?
Pardon my rudeneſs.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What does that concern
Thee Boy, 'tis a name cannot advantage thee,
And I am weary on't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Had you conceal'd,
Or I forgot it ſir, ſo large were my
Directions, that you could not ſpeak this language,
But I ſhould know you by your ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Thou
Wert well inform'd, it ſeems; well, what's your buſineſe?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I come to bring you comfort.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Is Maria
Alive agen? that's ſomewhat, and yet not
Enough to make my expectation riſe, to
Paſt half a bleſſing, ſince we cannot meet
To make it up a full one; th'art miſ • aken.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: VVhen you have heard me, you'le think otherwiſe:
In vain I ſhould report Maria living:
The comfort that I bring you muſt depend
Upon her death.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: T • 'art a diſſembling boy,
Some one has ſent thee to m •• k me, though my anger
Stoop 〈◊〉 to puniſh thy green years, unripe
For malice did I know what perſon ſent thee
To tempt my ſorrow thus, I ſhould revenge it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Indeed I have no thought ſo uncharitable,
Nor am I ſent to grieve you, let me ſuffer
More puniſhment than ever boy deſerv'd,
If you do find me falſe; I ſerve a Miſtreſs
VVould rather dye than play with your misfortunes;
Then good ſir hear me out.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: VVho is your Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Before I name her, give me ſome incouragement,
That you receive her meſſage, ſhe is one
That is full acquainted with your miſery,
And can bring ſuch a portion of her ſorrow
In every circumſtance ſo like your own,
You'le love and pity her, and wiſh your griefs
Might marry one anothers.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Thou art wild?
Canſt thou bring comfort from ſo ſad a creature?
Her miſerable ſtory can at beſt,
But ſwell my Volume, large enough already.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: She was late belov'd, as you were, promis'd faith,
And marriage, and was worthy of a better
Than he, that ſtole Maria's heart.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Juſt as Maria dealt with your affection,
Did he that married her, deal with my Miſtreſs,
VVhen careleſs both of honour and Religion;
They cruelly gave away their hearts to ſtrangers,

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Part of this truth I Know, but prethee boy
Proceed to that thou cam'ſt for; thou didſt promiſe
Something, thy language cannot hitherto
Encourage me to hope for.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That I come to:
My miſtreſs thus unkindly dealt with all,
You may imagine, wanted no affliction;
And had ere this, Wept her ſelf drye as marble,
Had not your fortune come to her relief,
And twinne to her own ſorrow brought her comfort.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Could the condition of my fate ſo equal,
Leſſen her ſufferings?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I know not how
Companions in grief ſometimes diminiſh
And make the preſſure eaſie, by degrees:
She threw her troubles off, remembring yours,
And from her pity of your wrongs, there grew
Affection to your perſon thus increas'd,
And with it, confidence, that thoſe whom Nature
Had made ſo even in their weight of ſorrow,
Could not but love as equally one another,
Were things but well prepar'd, this gave her boldneſs
To employ me thus far.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: A ſtrange meſſage boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: If you incline to meet my Miſtreſs love,
It may beget your comforts; beſides that,
'Tis ſome revenge, that you above their ſcorn
And pride, can laugh at them, whoſe perjury
Hath made you happy, and undone themſelves.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Have you done boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Onely this little more:
When you but ſee, and know my Miſtreſs well,
You will forgive my tediouſneſs, ſhe's fair,
Fair as Maria was.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Ile hear no more,
Go fooliſh Boy, and tell thy fonder Miſtreſs
And mine, was given to Maria, though her death
Allow me freedom, ſee the Picture of her.
I would give ten thouſand Empires for the ſubſtance;
Yet for Maria's ſake, whoſe divine Figure
That rude frame carries, I will love this counterfeit
Above all the world, and had had thy Miſtreſs all
The grace and bloſſom of her ſex; now ſhe
Is gone, that was walking a Spring of beauty,
I would not look upon her.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir, your pardon,
I have but done a meſſage, as becomes
A ſervant, nor did ſhe on whoſe commands
I gladly waited, bid me urge her love
To your diſquiet, ſhe wouldchide my diligence
If I ſhould make you angry.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Bretty Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Indeed I fear I have offended you:
Pray if I have, enjoyn me any pennance for it;
I have perform'd one duty, and could as willingly
To purge my fault, and ſhew I ſuffer with you,
Plead your cauſe to another.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: And Ile take thee
At thy word boy, thou haſt a moving language,
That pretty innocent, Copie of Maria
Is all I love, I know not how to ſpeak,
Winne her to think well of me, and I will.
Reward thee to thy wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I undertake
Nothing for gain, but ſince you have reſolv'd.
To love no other, Ile be faithful to you,
And my propheticke thoughts bid me already
Say I ſhall proſper.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Thou wert ſent to bleſs me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Pray give us opportunity.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Be happy.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: He's gone.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: With your fair leave Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Have you buſineſs with her pray you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I have a meſſage from a gentleman,
Pleaſe you vouchſafe your ear more private.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: You ſhall have my abſence Neece.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Was the ſentleman afeard to declare his matters openly, here was no bodies was not very honeſt, if her like not her errands the petter, was wiſt to keep her preathes to coole her porridges, can tell her that now for aule her private hearings and tawgings.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You may, if pleaſe you, find another language,
And with leſs pains be underſtood.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What is her meaning?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Come, pray ſpeak your own Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Have boyes loſt her itts and memories? bleſs us aule.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I muſt be plain then, come, I know you are

sp.speaker: Maria,
sp.l: this thinne vail cannot obſcure you:
Ile tell the world you live, I have not loſt yee,
Since firſt with griefe and ſhame to be ſurpris'd,
A violent trance took away ſhew of life;
I could diſcover by what accident
You were convey'd away at midnight, in
Your coffin, could declare the place, and minute,
When you reviv'd, and what you have done ſince as perfectly—

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Alas, I am betraid to new misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You are not for my knowledge, Ile be dumbe
For ever, rather than be ſuch a traytor;
Indeed I pity you, and bring no thoughts,
But full of peace, call home your modeſt blood,
Pale hath too long uſurp'd upon your face;
Think upon love agen, and the poſſeſſion
Of full blown joyes, now ready to ſalute you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Theſe words undo me more than my own griefes.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I ſee how fear would play the tyrant with you,
But Ile remove ſuſpition; have you in
Your heart an entertainment for his love,
To whom your Virgin faith made the firſt promiſe?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: If thou mean'ſt Hartlove, thou doſt wound me ſtill,
I have no life without his memory,
Nor with it any hope to keep it long,
Thou ſeeſt I walk in darkneſs like a theef,
That fears to ſee the world in his own ſhape,
My very ſhadow frights me, tis a death
To live thus, and not look day in the face,
Away, I know thee not.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You ſhall hereafter Know, and thank me Lady,
Ile bring you a diſcharge at my next viſit,
Of all your fears, be content fair Maria,
Tis worth your wonder.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Be wiſe and ſilent,
Dreſs your ſelf, you ſhall be what you wish.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Do this, and be
My better Angell.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: All your cares on me.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I Muſt applaud thy diligence.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: It had been nothing
To have left him in the Porch; I cal'd his ſervants,
With wonders they acknowledg'd him, I pretended
It was ſome ſpice, ſure of the falling ſickneſs,
And that was charity to bring him home;
They rub'd and chaf'd him, ply'd him with ſtrong water,
Still he was ſenſeleſs, clamors could not wake him;
I wiſhed 'em then get him to bed, they did ſo,
And almoſt fmothr'd him with rugges and pillows;
And 'cauſe they ſhould have no cauſe to ſuſpect me,
I watch'd them till he wak'd.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Twas excellent:

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: When his time came to yawn, and ſtretch himſelf,
I bid 'em not to be haſty to diſcover
How he was brought home; his eyes fully open,
With trembling he began to call his ſervants,
And told 'em he had ſeen ſtrange viſions,
That ſhould convert him from his Heathen courſes;
They wondred, and were ſilent, there he preach'd
How ſweet the air of a contended conſcience
Smelt in his noſe now, ask'd 'em all forgiveneſs
For their hard paſture ſince they liv'd with him;
Bid 'em believe, and fetch out the cold ſur-loin:
Pierce the ſtrong beer, and let the neighbours joy in't:
The conceal'd Muskadine ſhould now lye open
To every mouth; that he would give toth' poor,
And mend their wages; that his doors ſhould be
Open to every miſerable ſutor.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What ſaid his ſervants then?

sp.speaker: Boy,
sp.l: They durſt not ſpeak,
But bleſt themſelves, and the ſtrange means that had
Made him a Chriſtian in this over-joy,
I took my leave, and bad 'em ſay their prayers,
And humor him, leſt he turned Jew agen.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Enough, enough. Whoſe this?
'Tis one of my ringers; ſtand cloſe, my Ladies Coachman.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Buy a mat for a bed, buy a mat;
Would I were at rack and manger among my horſes;
We have devided the Sextons
Houſhould ſtuffe among us, one has the rugge, and he's
Turn'd Iriſh, and another has a blanket, and he muſt begge in't,
The ſheets ſerve another for a frock, and with the bed-cord,
He may paſs for a Porter, nothing but the mat would fall
To my ſhare, which with the help of a tune and a haſſocke
Out oth' the Church may diſguiſe me till I get home;
A pox a bell-ringing by the Ear, if any man take me
At it agen, let him pull mine to the Pillory, I could wiſh
I had loſt mine Ears, ſo I had my cloaths agen:
The wether wo'not allow this faſhion,
I do look for an ague beſides.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: How the raskal ſhakes?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: Here are company:
Buy a mat for a bed, buy a mat,
A haſſocke for your feet, or a Piſs clean and ſweet;
Buy a mat for a bed, buy a mat:
Ringing, I renounce thee, Ile never come to Church more.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You with a mat?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: I am call'd.
If any one ſhould oſffer to buy my mat, what a caſe were I in?
Oh that I were in my Oat-tub with a horſe loaf,
Something to hearten me:
I dare not hear 'em;
Buy a mat for a bed, Buy a mat.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: He's deaf.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: I am glad, I am: buy a mat for a bed.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: How the raskal ſweats? What a pickle he is in?
Every ſtreet he goes through will be a new torment.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.l: If ever I meet at midnight more a jangling:
I am cold, and yet I drop; buy a mat for a bed, buy a mat.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: He has puniſhment enough.
Who's this, my tother youth? he is turn'd Bear.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I am half afraid of my ſelf: this poor ſhift
I got oth' Sexton to convey me hanſomely
To ſome harbour, the wench will hardly know me;
They'le take me for ſome Watchman oth' pariſh;
I ha ne're a penny left me, thats one comfort;
And ringing has begot a monſtrous ſtomacke,
And thats another miſchiefe, I were beſt go home,
For every thing will ſcorne me in this habit.
Beſides, I am ſo full of theſe young bell ringers;
If I get in adoors, not the power oth' countrey,
Nor all my Aunts curſes ſhall diſembogue me.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Bid her come hither preſently,—hum; tis he. Exit. Ser.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I am betraid to one that will eternally laugh at me,
Three of theſe rogues will Jeere a horſe to death.

sp.speaker: Lun.
sp.l: Tis Mr. Wildbrain ſure, and yet me thinks
His faſhion's ſtrangely altred; ſirra Watchman,
You rugamuffin. turn you louzie bears skinne:
You with the bed-rid bill.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Ha'ſt found me out;
There's no avoiding him, I had rather now
Be arraign'd at Newgate for a robberie
Than anſwer to his Articles: your will ſir,
I am in haſte.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nay then I will make bold wo' yee;
A Watchman and aſham'd to ſhew his countenance,
His face of authority; I have ſeen that phyſiognomy;
Were you never in priſon for pilfering?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: How the rogue worries me.

sp.speaker: Lur,
sp.l: Why may not this
Be the villain rob'd my houſe laſt night,
And walks diſguis'd in this malignant rugge,
Arm'd with a tunne of Iron, I will have you
Before a Magiſtrate.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What art thou? ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I am the wandring Jew, and pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: By your leave Rabbi, I will ſhew you then
A Synagogue, iclip't Bridewell, where you
Vnder correction may reſt your ſelf;
You have brought a bill to guard you, there be dogwhips
To firke ſuch rugg'd curres, whips without bells
Indeed.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Bells.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: How he ſweats?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I muſt be known, as good at firſt; now; jeere on,
But do not anger me too impudently,
The Rabbi will be mov'd then.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: How? lacke Wildbrain.
What time oth' Moon man, ha? what ſtrange bells
Haſt in thy brains.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No more bells,
No more bells, they ring backwards.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Why, where's the wench the bleſſing that befell thee?
The unexpected happineſs? where's that lacke?
VVhere are thy golden dayes?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: It was his tricke as ſure as I am louſie,
But how to be reveng'd—

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Fie, fie, Iacke,
Marry a watchmans widdow in thy young dayes,
VVith a revennew of old Iron, and a rugge:
Is this the Paragon, the dainty Piece,
The delicate divine Rogue?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Tis enough I am undone,
Mark'd for a miſery, and ſo leave prating;
Give me my bill.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You • eed not aske your Taylors,
Vnleſs you had better linings; it may be
To avoid ſuſpition you are going thus
Diſguis'd to your fair Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Mocke no further,
Or as I live Ile lay my bill o'thy pate,
Ile take a watchmans fury into my fingers,
To ha no judgement to diſtinguiſh perſons
And knocke thee down.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Come, I ha done, and now
VVill ſpeake ſome comfort to thee, I will lead thee
Now to my Miſtreſs hitherto conceal'd;
She ſhall take pity on thee too, ſhe loves
A ha • ſome man; thy miſery invites me
To do thee good, Ile not be jealous lacke;
Her beauty ſhall commend it ſelf; but do not
VVhen I have brought you into grace ſupplant me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Art thou in earneſt, by this could Iron—

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No oathes, I am not coſtive; here ſhe comes
Sweet heart, I have brought a gentleman,
A friend of mint to be acquainted with you,
He's other than he ſeems; why d'ee ſtare thus?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Oh ſir, forgive me, I have done ye wrong.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What's the matter? didſt ever ſee her aſore Jack?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Prethee do what thou wo't wo'me, if thou haſt
A mind, hang me up quickly.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Never deſpair, Ile give thee my ſhare rather,
Take her, I hope ſhe loves thee at firſt ſight,
She has Peticoates will patch thee up a ſuit;
I reſign all, onely Ile keep theſe trifles,
I took ſome pains for'em, I take it Jack;
What thing you pinke of beauty, come let me
Counſel you both to marry, ſhe has a trade,
If you have audacity to hook in Gamſters:
Let's ha a wedding, you will be wondrous rich;
For ſhe is impudent, and thou art miſerable;
'T will be a rare match.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: As you are a man forgive me, Ile redeem all.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Yo wo'not to this geer of marriage then?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: No, no, I thank you Tom, I •• n watch for
A groat a night, and be every gentlemans fellow. Exit Mi.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Riſe, and be good, keep home and tend your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Thou hak don't to purpoſe, give me thy hand Tom;
Shall we be friends? thou ſeeſt what ſtate I am in,
Ile undertake this pennance to my Aunt,
Juſt as I am, and openly Ile go;
Where, if I be received again for currant,
And fortune ſmile once more—

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I'me ſatisfied, ſo farewel honeſt louzie Jack.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I cannot help it, ſome men meet with ſtrange deſtinies.
If things go right thou maiſt be hang'd, and I
May live to ſee't, and purchaſe thy apparel:
So farewel Tom, commend me to thy Polcat. Exit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Now that I have my counſel ready, and my cauſe ripe;
The Judges all inform'd of the abuſes;
Now that he ſhould be gone.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: No man knows whether,
And yet they talk he went forth with a Conſtable
That told him of ſtrange buſineſs, that would bring him
Money and lands, and heaven knows what; but they
Have ſearch'd, and cannot find out ſuch an Officer:
And as a ſecret, Madam, they told your man
Nicholas, whom you ſent thither as a ſpie;
They had a ſhrewd ſuſpition 'twas the devil
Ith' likeneſs of a Conſtable, that has tempted him
By this time to ſtrange things; there have been men
As rich as he, have met convenient rivers,
And ſo forth; many trees have born ſtrange fruits:
De'e think he has not hang'd himſelf?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: If he be hang'd, who has his goods?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: They are forfeited, they ſay.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He has hang'd himſelf for certain then,
Onely to coſen me of my Girles portion.

sp.speaker: Nu.
sp.l: Very likely.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Or not did the Conſtable carry him to ſome priſon?

sp.speaker: Nu.
sp.l: They thought on that too, and ſearch'd every where.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He may be cloſe for treaſon, perhaps executed.

sp.speaker: Nu.
sp.l: Nay, they did look among the quarters too,
And muſtered all the bridge-houſe for his night-cap.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Madam, here is the gentleman agen.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He that lov'd my young Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas, 'tis Hartlove, 'twill but feed his melancholly,
To let him ſee Maria, ſince we dare not
Yet tell the world ſhe lives; and certainly,
Did not the violence of his paſſion blind him.
He would ſee paſt her borrowed tongue and habit.

sp.speaker: Nis.
sp.l: Pleaſe you entertain him a while Madam,
Ile caſt about for ſomething with your daughter.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Do what thou wor, pray Mr. Hartlove enter.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Madam, I come to ask your gentle pardon.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Pardon, for what? you ne're offended me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Yes, if ye be the mother of Maria.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I was her mother, but that word is cancel'd,
And buried with her in that very minute
Her ſoul fled from her, We loſt both our names
Of mother and of daughter.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Alas, Madam,
If your relation did conſiſt but in
Thoſe naked terms, I had a title nearer,
Since love unites more than the tie of blood;
No matter for the empty voice of mother;
Your nature ſtill is left, which in her abſence
Muſt love Maria, and not ſee her aſhes
And memory polluted.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You amaze me, by whom?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: By me, I am the vile profaner.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why do you ſpeak thus indiſcreetly ſir?
You ever honour'd her.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I did alive,
But ſince ſhe died, I ha been a villain to her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I do beſeech you ſay not ſo; all this
Is but to make me know, how much I ſinn'd
In forcing her to marry—

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Do not mocke me,
I charge you by the Virgin you have wept for;
For I have done an impious act againſt her,
A deed able to fright her from her ſleep,
And through her marble, oft to be reveng'd;
A wickedneſs, that if I ſhould be ſilent,
You as a witneſs muſt accuſe me for't.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Was I a witneſs?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Yes, you knew I lov'd:
Maria once; or grant, you did but think ſo,
By what I ha profeſt, or ſhe has told you,
Was't not a fault unpardonable in me,
VVhen I ſhould drop my tears upon her grave,
Yes, and proof ſufficient.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: To what?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: That I forgetfull of my fame and vowes.
To fair Maria, ere the Worm could pierce
Her tender ſhroud, had chang'd her for another;
Did you not bluſh to ſee me turne a Rebell?
So ſoon to court a ſhadow, a ſtrange thing,
VVithout a name? Did you not curſe my levity,
Or think upon her death with the leſs ſorrow
Thatſhe had ſcap'd a puniſhment more killing,
Oh how I ſhame to think on't.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sir in my
Opinion, 'twas an argument of love
To your Maria, for whoſe ſake you could
Affect one that but carried her ſmall likeneſs.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: No more, you are too charitable, but
I know my guilt, and will from henceforth never
Change words with that ſtrange maid, whoſe innocent face:
Like your Maria's won ſo late upon me,
My paſſions are corrected, and I can
Look on her now, and woman kind, without
Love in a thought; 'tis thus, I came to tell you,
If after this acknowledgement, you'le be
So kind to ſhew me in what ſilent grave
You have diſpos'd your daughter, I will ask
Forgiveneſs of all her duſt, and never leave,
Till with a loud confeſſion of my ſhame
I wake her ghoſt, and that pronounce my pardon:
Will you deny this favour? then farewell,
Ile never ſee you more: ha!
sp.stage: Enter Nurſe, Maria in her own apparel, after ſome ſhew of wonder he goes toward her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Be not deluded ſir, upon my life
This is the ſoul whom you but thought Maria
In my daughters habit; what did you mean Nurſe?
I knew ſhe would but cozen you, is ſhe not like now?
One dew unto another is not nearer.

sp.speaker: Nu.
sp.l: She thinks ſhe is a gentlewoman;
And that imagination has ſo taken her,
She ſcorns to ſpeak, how handſomly ſhe carries it,
As if ſhe were a well bred thing, her body?
And I warrant you, what looks?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Pray be not fooliſh.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I di • turb no body, ſpeak but half a word
And I am ſatisfied, but what needs that?
Ile ſwear 'tis ſhe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But do not, I beſeech you,
For truſt me ſir, you know not what I know.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Peace then,
And let me pray, ſhe holds up her hands with me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This will betray all.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Love ever honor'd,
And ever young, thou Soveraign of all hearts,
Of all our ſorrows, the ſweet eaſe,
Does ſhe ſtill coſen me?

sp.speaker: Nu.
sp.l: You will ſee anon,
'Twas her deſire, expect the iſſue Madam.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: My ſoul's ſo bigge, I cannot pray; 'tis ſhe,
I will go nearer.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Here's Mr. Algripe, and other ſtrangers Madam.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Here good Lady,
Upon my knees I ask thy worſhips pardon;
Here's the whole ſumme I had with thy fair daughter;
Would ſhe were living, I might have her peace too,
And yield her up again to her old liberty:
I had a wife before, and could not marry;
My pennance ſhall be on that man that honor'd her,
To conferre ſome land.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This is incredible.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Tis truth.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Do you know me ſir?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ha, the gentleman I deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My name is Lurcher.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: 'Shat have thy morgage.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I ha that already, no matter for the deed
If you releaſe it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Ile do't before thy witneſs;
But Where's thy ſiſter? if ſhe live I am happy, though
I conceal our contract, which was
Stoln from me with the evidence of this land.
sp.stage: The Boy goes to Maria and gives her a paper; ſhe wonders, and ſmiles upon Hartlove, he amaz'd approaches her: afterward ſhe ſhews it her mother, and then givis it to Hartlove.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Your daughter ſmiles.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I hope ſhe lives, but where, I cannot tell ſir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Even here, and pleaſe you ſir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis ſhe;
To work thy fair way, I preſerved you brother,
That would have loſt me willingly, and ſerv'd ye
Thus like a boy; I ſerved you faithfully,
And caſt your plots to preſerve your credit;
Your foul ones I diverted to fair uſes;
So far as you would hearken to my counſel;
That all the world may know how much you owe me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Welcome entirely, welcome my dear Alathe,
And when I loſe thee agen, bleſſing forſake me:
Nay, let me kiſs thee in theſe cloaths.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And I too,
And bleſs the time I had ſo wiſe a ſiſter, wer't thou the little thief?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I ſtole the contract, I muſt confeſs,
And kept it to my ſelf, it moſt concern'd me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Contracted? this diſtroyes his after marriage.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Dare you give this hand
To this young gentleman, my heart goes with it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Maria alive! how my heart's exalted, 'tis my duty;
Take her Frank Hartlove, take her; and all joyes
With her; beſides ſome lands to advance her Joynture:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What I have is your own, and bleſſings crown ye.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Give me room,
And freſh air to conſider, gentlemen,
My hopes are too high.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Be more temperate,
Or Ile be Welſh again.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A day of wonder.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Lady, your love, I ha kept my word; there was
A time, when my much ſuffering made me hate you,
And to that end I did my beſt to croſs you:
And fearing you were dead I ſtole your Coffin,
That you might never more uſurp my office:
Many more knacks I did, which at the Weddings
Shall be told of as harmleſs tales.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Hollow your throats a pieces, I am at home;
If you can roar me out again—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What thing is this?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A continent of fleas: room for the Pageant;
Make room afore there; your kinſman Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My kinſman? let me wonder!

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Do, and Ile wonder too, to ſee this company
At peace one with another; 'tis not worth
Your admiration, I was never dead yet;
Ye'are merry Aunt, I ſee, and all your company:
If ye be not, Ile fool up, and provoke ye?
I will do any thing to get your love again:
Ile forſwear midnight, Taverns and temptations;
Give good example to your Grooms, the maids
Shall go to bed and take their reſt this year;
None ſhall appear with bliſters in their bellies.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And when you will fool again, you may go ring.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Madam, have mercy.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Your ſubmiſſion ſir,
I gladly take, we will
Enquire the reaſon of this habit afterwards;
Now you are ſoundly ſham'd, well we reſtore you:
Where's Toby?
Where's the Coachman?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: He's a bed, Madam.
And has an ague, he ſayes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Ile be his Phyſitian.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: We muſt a foot then.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: E're the Prieſt ha done
Toby ſhall wait upon you with his Coach,
And make your Flanders Mares dance back agen we'ye,
I warrant you Madam you are mortified,
Your ſute shall be granted too.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Make, make room afore there.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Home forward with glad hearts, home child.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I wait you.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: On joyfully, the cure of all our grief,
Is owing to this pretty little Thief.
